Overall Impression: 
Alright, Kramer, ticking this one just for you buddy!  Not a bad beer at all, but still not significantly better then anything else in this style for me to really have a strong feeling about it.  I wanted to really like it, I did.  However, it is really just solid, highly drinkable, but just unexciting...and you could really describe my entire opinion on this style that way.  It really isnt much better then the standards like Hofbrau, Hacker-Pschorr, Sam Adams, etc.

Pours light amber colored with huge white cloudy head.  Rather light malty aroma with hints of bread and caramel.  Flavor is primarily caramel and lightly roasted malts but well balanced so its not as sweet as some Oktoberfests.  Very smooth, clean finish.

(Draught) clear deep amber, ring of fine white bubbles. Node of vanilla, yam, brown sugar, sweet butter cream. Taste is malty sweet, yam, very smooth and drinkable, sweet cracker, medium body, yam linger. Excellent Oktoberfest.

First rating for the Oktoberfest/Marzen style, and this is the #1 beer in the style.  With Oktoberfest just around the corner (and today being the first day of autumn), I thought I would finally open this one.  500 ml bottle purchased ten months ago at Trader Joes in Escondido ($2.99).  Pours a clear golden amber hue with a big three fingers of off-white head.  Aroma of bready malts, wet grains, honey, and some ripe fruit (notable grape).  Flavor of caramel, honey, grainy toasted bread, and a bit of fruitiness.  Mildly sweet with only a bit of perceptible hops.  Actually pretty nice, but I somehow imagine this tasting better out of a large stein in Munich this time of year (though I understand that Ayinger beer is not actually available at the official Oktoberfest).  (1023, 735)
Clear dark gold with a healthy white head. Crisp, dry and grainy palate. Light to medium bodied. Very hoppy on the finish.
Dark bronze/orange. Caramel, bananas, spices, wheat, grass. Light body, creamy texture.

Pours a clear bronze golden with a large white head. Beautiful aroma, lightly sweet of caramel, toast, and hay. Even the smell puts me in a fall mood. Nice full body delivers a good malty sweetness throughout and some graininess. A slight hint of smoke to snuff the sweetness towards the end of the sip, more hay flavors, amazingly complex for such an easy drinker. Finishes crisp, lightly bitter and dry. A very nice Oktoberfest, Im not huge on this style but Ayinger is the best example Ive been able to find on this side of the pond. To me this is the benchmark Oktoberfest and I regularly drink this during the fall from September - Halloween. I would much rather have a well done Oktoberfest than yet another overly sweet and spiced pumpkin ale that is so popular with American craft brewers these days. This beer to me is world class for the style and truly remarkable.
Hazy light amber color with huge head. Aroma is grassy, malty. Flavour is malty, bitter.

Bottle, thanks Ayinger provider Hirigalzkar.
Pours redish amber with a cream white head.
Aroma of sponge cake and fallen leaves.
Malty taste, kandi sugar finishes with a fruity bitterness and slightly burnt white bread.Earlier Rating: 10/9/2011 Total Score: 3.5Draught at Bishops arms Folkungagatan.
Pours amber with a little head.
Malty with a bit more hops than usual in combination with a rather big body that makes it taste like an old US DIPA

50cl bottle from Alko. Poured amber w. a steady white head. Malty, biscuity aroma, but also some berry-like notes. Flavor has bready malt, hops, light alcohol. Drinkable, but alcohol coming through too much.

Copper, clear color, thin head. Typical otoberrest taste, malty and some caramel.

A beautiful, reddish beer with a medium and blond head. Aroma of smooth malts, toffee, hint of berries and of smoke. Nice aroma, but its difficult to get out aromas. Taste is malty and bready, hint of roastiness and smoke, aftertaste is nicely dry. Medium bodied, nice to drink. High-quality and enjoyable beer again from Ayinger.

Bottle. Pours a pale orange with a fluffy white head. The nose is pretty generic. Some fruity malts, faint grassy hops. Clean overall. On tasting, moderate sweetness, pretty bland overall. Clean. Not a lot to say really. Okay but the US fresh ones seem better.Earlier Rating: 1/4/2012 Total Score: 3.4Draft at Map Room. Id call this a Landbier, but whatever. Unfiltered Festbier. Pours a deep reddish brown with an offwhite head. The nose is bready, lots of bread crust and melanoidins. Faint hops with a yeasty note. On tasting, on the sweeter side and a crispness to it. Medium-full bodied. Lots of the bread character that sticks through the finish. A touch oxidized as well but a pretty interesting beer overall.

50 cl, bottled. Pours cloudy orange with a decent white head. Aroma: Malt, biscuits. Brown sugar. Herbs. Taste: Medium sweet, some bitterness. Lots of malty  biscuits in flavours. Palate: Near med body, noticeable carbonation.
I must have tried a different beer than everyone here. Mine tasted just like a standard pale lager.

Shared bottle to snifter (thanks DrSilverworm). Looks good; a transparent light-orange with thin white lacing. Smells solid; malty, golly, and pleasantly skunky. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel. A great example of the style.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2015 500ml bottle. Clear orange color. Thin off-white head. Continuously ascending bubbles in the body. Some loose lace. Stronger carbonation, at first. Nice toasty caramel malt aroma. Smooth, some spice. Some fruitiness.  Light sweet, light bitter taste. One of the more enjoyable German festbiers Ive tried. Love the 16.9oz size, great to enjoy with a sandwich. 7/3/6/3/13Re-rate, 9/9/15: On tap at Dutchs. Clear amber golden orange color. Thin off-white head. Loose ropes and bits of lace. Medium plus body. Smooth, kind of soft,  moderate carbonation. Soft, mild effervescent texture makes this a nice one to scrub down my short rib grilled cheese sandwich with. Nice peppery flavor, some fruitiness, mild caramel and good toastiness. Good bit of earthy, mildly floral hop. Moderate bitter taste, lighter to moderate sweet. Very solid, classic oktoberfest.

Pours a amber orange with a small off white head that quickly fades.  aroma is of baked bread, some biscuit malts, caramel, and some mild hop bitterness.  Taste is well balaced and is of baked bread, pretzels, some toasted malts, caramel, and some general hop bitterness.  has a medium body with semi creamy mouthfeel and a semi, dry, sweet finish.  overall,. a very nice marzen that goes great with German food.

No bottling information.

A: The body is a nice clear amber/orange hued with bits of lazy carbonation in the body with a dense light tan head that sits nicely on-top filling out the glass, though poor retention.

S: The aroma is a bit faint but theres a light caramel sweetness with a light fruity tone with hints of earthy and toasted tones.

T: The intro has a very lightly toasted flavor that leads into a sweet, but not overly prominent, caramel with hints of fruit that stick through to the finish.

M: A medium creamy bodied beer.

O: This is pretty unremarkable, meaning I wont remember it, but its a solid beer and very easy to drink. There is good balance here, unlike many American versions that are too sweet.

Easy drinking, well balanced beer that has the same inviting maltiness as other examples of the style, but without the oft lingering sweetness. Creamy feeling natural carbonation is there for those who can appreciate it. Try this one before you say you dont like Fest biers.
Aroma of roasted grain, bread, a touch of caramel, and floral hops. Mild taste with some hop bitterness, grain, and a bit of ashes. Slick mouthfeel. Very drinkable.

Bottle. Light amber, hazy, small to average and fully diminishing head. Moderate, malty and sweetish aroma, some caramel and some bread. Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, some caramel and some bread. Finish is average, malty and sweetish, light caramel and some bread with faint hoppyness. Too sweet/too much bread - lacks almost totally the bitterness.

500ml bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a clear medium copper with a two finger fluffy white head. Excellent head retention and decent lacing.

Aroma is fairly subdued with hints of caramel, toffee, and a little toast. Also some hay presumably from the hops.

The flavor, like the aroma, is also subdued. Creamy caramel up front followed by some cereal grain and a little bit of toasted malt. There is almost a hint of smokiness towards the back in. Light grassy hop flavors along with a light bitterness to balance out the sweet malt. The mouthfeel is quite dry for the style which to me, drastically helps drinkability.

Overall, one of my favorite Oktoberfests. My one complaint is that the aroma and flavor is a little too subdued. That aside, the drinkability is incredible and I could easily put back lots of this in a sitting.

The oktoberfest against which I compare all others at this point.  Tried as part of a fall beer tasting session with James, the Cunigans, and Jess.  Was incredibly impressed with the balance of this beer.  Solid caramel foundation, somewhat sweet with a medium body and smooth mouthfeel.  Imminently drinkable.

500ml bottle from Wegmans, King of Prussia, PA. A bright amber pour with a ring of white head; light caramel malt aroma; rather sweet with a caramel malt flavour, becoming drier with some light floral hops and a doughy body. Very pleasant, but somehow I was expecting far more.

500 ml bottle as Ayinger Kirtabier. L2233. BB 05/13. (Alko) Kuopio, Finland.
Hazy red brown colour with big fluffy off-white head. 
Malty aroma with some sweet, yeast and earth notes. 
Flavour is mild hoppy bitterness, some sweetness, earthy malt and touch of alcohol. Quite warming. Not bad. Earlier Rating: 9/15/2010 Total Score: 3.2Draught at One Pint Pub, Helsinki, Finland.
Clear copper colour with small creamy off-white head.
Malt, sweet sugar and floral hops in aroma.
Grainy malt, dry hops, alcohol and floral hops in flavour.

Draught at Amsterdam, Helsinki, Finland.
Clear amber colour with tiny white head.
Malt, sweet sugar and mild floral hops in aroma.
Malt, wood, mild bitterness and grassy hops in dry flavour.
On tap at TnD. Pours golden with two finger white head. Floral, caramel, straw. Lightly bitter and moderately sweet. Medium, smooth bodied. Pretty good lager type.
Orange/red/brown wierd but good looking colour. Best thing about this beer though, aroma was ok , but the taste was just caramel sweetness and nothing more, next beer plz.

Pours hazy amber with a head that fades away compeletely really quickly. Aroma has lots of malts in it - hay, bread - and a touch of toffee. Taste is full of bready maltiness; not much else is in it. Dryish herbal notes appear in the aftertaste and balance a little, but malts are dominant. Light to medium bodied, slick, easy to drink. Simple but not bad.
Pours copper with white head. Aroma of toffee and loads of malt. Flavour of malt and herbal hops. Rather simple but good.

This is my favorite Oktoberfest beer. Pours a medium copper with an off-white one finger head. Nice balance with between the hops and lightly roasted malts. Appropriate carbonation and great overall appearance. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Citrus sweet smell and taste with some earthy grass. Super smooth and drinkable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
perfume, lemon, apple, golden, sparkling, frothy, heavy cloying sweetness, light body, thin feel, fizzy

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2012 Ok so this is the best of the best with oktoberfests    i had to try     bready malts aroma and spicy clove notes   dry finish but the body is sweet bready malt    not my favorite

Clear light amber pour with a foamy white head. Aroma is sweet & cream bread malts with light hints of earthy hops. Flavor is similar and ends on a crisp dryness with a hint of floral bitterness. Pretty decent Oktoberfest.
Tap@ social reform bar. Only draft in DC  due too opening a new cigarbar close to the German embassy. Golden clear. One finger foam. Faint malty notes. Crisp pilzner like. A bit boring.
Toffee and caramel aromas. Toffee and nut flavors with a little hop more at the end. Overall a decent fest beer.
Pours cloudy amber with low head. Aroma is malts, herbs and hint of dried fruits. Flavor it alcohol, bitter näkyy fruits.

Pours cloudy amber with a low head. Aroma is grainy malts. Flavor is full malts with some hops. Decent.Earlier Rating: 10/5/2011 Total Score: 3.4Pours deep golden with a medium head. Aroma is sweetish malts. Flavor is malts, caramel and perhaps some nuts. Quite complex for such a light flavor.

Bottled (from Alko Prisma, Vaasa). Amber colour, big creamy off-white head, that leaves some lace. Aroma is bready and quite sweet malts along with some slight earth, grass and some herbal notes. Flavour is big time bready malts, grassy hops and some gentle floral and herbal notes as well. Rather big bitterness in the finish. Quite bitter for being an Oktoberfest/Märzen beer. Earlier Rating: 9/27/2005 Total Score: 3.1Bottled. Copper coloured, beige thick creamy huge head. Malts and hops in aroma, along with hay and caramel. Strong flavour of hops and malt. Wellbalanced and pleasant. A bit roast and honey in aftertaste.
Clear amber pour, some white head. Malt forward with the right amount of hops to help balance it. A typical German brew that is well done.

Superb amber profile, glowing with lovely herbal aroma. Floral scent lingers long after a sip. Great body and full taste, goes down easy and clear. Delightful aftertaste of malt and dry mature flavor.

Slight copper hue, huge off white head.  Roasted malt and hops in the nose.  Light caramel sweetness on the tongue.  Heading into the finish the body is perfectly balanced between thick malt and refreshing alcohol and slightly spicy hops. Great by itself, magnificent with food (roast chicken & sweet potatoes for me).  I could drink this almost anytime.

Bought at Trader Joes, and served in dimpled mug. Feint aroma of  sweet rolls and fruit jam. Light copper  color, brilliantly clear, thick foamy spongy white head. Easy drink, build flavor as it develops in your mouth. First and foremost, it is smooth, like velvet. Medium body ,  slightly crisp and dry at the end. Flavor  of bread, and mild  clover honey.  It is mid September, so this Oktoberfest hits the season. Hard to have just one.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2012 A classic octoberfest from Deutschland...lagered nicely!  The malt notes shine through and the hops are just right for tne style.  Color, clarity perfect!  Ayinger is one of the classic producers of octoberfest; this beer should be experienced every year! Textbook marzen; easy drinking.  Pairs well with food; especially the chicken wings Im eating with it!  Good drink!

Bottle.  Perfectly clear amber with a thin white head.  Aroma is very malty, nutty, caramel, with some grassy hops.  Taste is mild-medium  sweet, mild bitter.   Finish is lightly dry/bitter with some spice.  Medium bodied, well carbonated.  Nothing spectacular, but I could see drinking a few of these at a Biergarten in Munich.

Bottle. Pours brownish orange with a small and fast dissapearing white head. Spicy (ginger) yet sweet (milk chocolate) aroma. The taste has a lot of the bitter-sweet marzipan notes that are usually found in bockbiers. Flowery hops. Warming. Overall: darker... heavier... and not as refreshing as Ayinger beers usually are.Earlier Rating: 10/9/2011 Total Score: 3.5On tap @ Bishops folkungagatan. We all know what Ayinger can do with the malts. This beer has got the usual and quite heavy malt profile. It reminds me of dark marzipan. This beer is however quite hoppy at the same time. Which add a fresh, floral touch. Small crispiness.

(Bottled, "Ayinger Kirtabier") Hazy red-copper with a medium, firm head. Toffee-bready-malty nose with buttery diacetyl hints and a touch of metal. Flavor is very bready-malty, sweetish and toffeeish, yet the sweetness remains well in balance, and there is also some ripe fruitiness. Medium to full body, soft and foamy CO2, filling palate. Very nice, filling and balanced autumn beer with nothing irritating, but the faintest touch of metal in the nose. 5336Earlier Rating: 9/20/2004 Total Score: 3.5(Draught) Light amber color with a  medium, white and lacy head. Slightly caramely, malty and aromatic-flowery-grassy-hoppy nose with buttery maltiness Softly, but nicely hoppy, berryish, somewhat salty-nutty and caramely flavor. Medium-bodied palate with quite low and smooth carbonation. A nice, aromatic, buttery, berry-fruity märzen.

Beautiful orange/amber color, crystal clear, good white head and pretty good lacing.

Malty like an Octoberfest should be.  Plenty of caramel malts and honey.  Nuts and bread.  Flavor and aroma are in sync.  Hops are limited and not especially notable.  

Body is light and slightly slick, toasty finish.

A nice Octoberfest.  Quite drinkable.  I found this one in a 16oz single but Id certainly buy a sixer of it.

Draught @ Olutravintiola Kahdet Kasvot as Ayinger Fest‐Märzen. Rated on 16.09.2010
Aroma has grainy and slightly sweet malt, some grassy hops and hints of butter. Flavour has some sweetish malt, grassy hops and hints of butter. Refreshing, faithful to the style and good!Earlier Rating: 9/9/2012 Total Score: 3.2
50 cl bottle @ home as Ayinger Kirtabier, BBE 05/2013
Aroma is somewhat sour with earthy notes and some sweetish, grainy malt. Flavour is somewhat tart and sour with lemon, some grainy malt and hints of apples. Not your typical Märzen, feels more like a kellerbier.
Clear amber light bodied Marzen with floral hop aroma, hint of caramel, crisp easy drinker.  Color a few shades lighter than American O-Fests and bit more flavorful.

Pours clear gold/lt amber with a medium white head...lively...great lacing and retention.  aroma has light roastiness, dry leaves, very light fruitiness.  Flavor follows suit...just a touch of earthy hoppiness.  Mouthfeel is full and silky with a earthy/dry leaves finish.
Pours a clear amber with a minimal white head.  Smells of bread, nuts, floral.  Taste is sweet and mildly bitter - maltiness abounds with a nice hop presence.

Bottled 500ml (Alko, BB 05/2013)"Ayinger Kirtabier". 
Slightly hazy amber color, steady creamy off-white head. Woody malty nose with hints of caramalt. Perharps some vegetable-sourness lurking in the background. Medium-bodied. Caramalt, bready maltyness, some leafy hoppyness in the aftertaste. Solid Märzen, although not the best of Ayinger.Earlier Rating: 10/3/2004 Total Score: 3.5Draught
Dark honey brown, good cloudy head. Aroma is crisp, lemon and berries. Malty with grassy hops. Pleasant mouthfeel. Really good beer for celebration of Oktoberfest.(5/4/7/4/14 3.4)
Re-rated, draught
Copper brown, small steady white head, lots of lace. Floral hoppy nose. Dry, chalky, hoppy flavor with typical märzen notes. Dry long aftertaste. One of the best of this style. (6/4/7/4/14 3.5)

Hazy deep amberwith big frothy head that covers aromas, medium long head. Mild aroma has bread.  Taste is bitterish, slightly sweet, spicy, light to medium body, fizzy bit thin feel and carbonation, medium long finish is bit sweet, ripe fruits here also, some nuts and caramel.  Ok beer, still I feel that something is missing..

500 ml bottle as Ayinger Kirtabier.
Pours an unclear amber orange colour with a small head. Aroma of grainy malts, toasted nuts and grass. Flavour of grainy malts, toasted nuts, chocolate,  bread, caramel and some dry wood. Medium bodied, slick mouthfeel and a rough, grainy malty finish. Quite close to a Dunkel.Earlier Rating: 10/8/2010 Total Score: 3Tap @ Ravintola Gloria, Kuopio.
Pours a clear copper colour with a minimal white head. Aroma of grainy malts and mild hops. Flavour of rye, grainy malts and mild honey. Medium bodied, quite high carbonation. Slick mouthfeel. Malty finish. Very drinkable Märzen brew.

Perfectly colored Oktoberfest lager. Sits easily on the palate. Aroma isn't amazing, but it tastes good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clear Autumn amber, with thin disappearing head.  Weak caramel and hop nose, barely perceptible minerals in background.  It has a nectar like sweetness of toffee and breads, just short of being balanced out with the hops.  Light in body and flavor, but it goes down smooth.  Clean finish.  Nothing outstanding.

Sweet hoppy and light aroma. Clear and dark yellow color. Wheat flavor is the strongest. A nice blend of spices. Light finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Smells a tad stale and yeast, with some wheatyness. First hits the tongue with the same yeastyness, but is abated by the carbonation and wheatyness. Oily but light.

The flavor on this is amazing.  More fruit flavors than a pack of skittles. Wonderful malt with a beautiful hop match.  Flaws come out on aroma (not much) appearance (chill haze, meh).  Since I bought this a few months ago and it came from the other side of the globe, storage may have added to the flaws.  Quite please with this.

Wow, Im surprised I havent seen this one before now.  Good continental 500 mL bottle, decent label, good crown with a pastoral brewfest.  Clear, intense burnt orange color, with an almost-white head.  Very nice, sweetish, nutty malt aroma.  My flavor profile analysis is probably going to be thrown off by the fresh pineapple which I had immediately prior to sampling this... It had an initial mineral presentation with a respectable bittering, then became biscuity with a slightly sweet vodka finish.  Good carbonation, medium body.  Overall, the beer was extremely balanced and well executed.  This would be a great beer with just about any kind of food - pizza, sausage, roast chicken.  Contemplating making some beer braised cabbage for dinner, I wish I had picked up another of these to use for that purpose.  Market Square Liquors, Timberlane.

Pours a golden ochre color with a finger or so eggshell foam.  Aromas are big sweet honeyed malts with light touches of floral hops peaking through.  On the palate it follows suit with a nice medium carbonation thats helps deliver the lightly sweet malty flavors from the field to your taste buds.  Fresh round wheat notes balanced beautifully with a slight floral bitterness... Yum

Dayton, Ohio, 29th Annual GermanFest Picnic. 500 ML bottle. Slightly skunky aroma. Nice head. Fizzy mouthfeel. Subdued, spice flavor. Subdued alcohol aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very nice amber appearance with a malty and sweet taste that finishes clean and smooth. Easy to drink and a decent beer.
Lots of white head, great lacing, creamy.  Clear golden color.  Malty flowery aroma.  Slight metallic finish, medium body.

From the bottle to a glass.  That Euro-lager aroma is dominant, but I STILL cant place a comparison.  The best I can describe it is damp earthy rocks near a freshwater body of water.  No moldy scent, just damp, cool, and fresh.  Taste is fresh with some sweet notes here and there.  There is just the slightest, and I mean slightest touch of banana candy.  Overall, an excellent lager.  I love it.  Re-rate notes: Just want to add that no matter what the style, the Bavarians do the best brews.
A little above your average average Octoberfest brew, and gets tastier after a while, but not a market leader.

Bottle served in a lager glass. Pours clear, watery, dark orange with a short head. Nice aroma of bready malt. Medium sweet flavor of nutty, toasted malt. Medium body, average carbonation, creamy-oily texture, and a long, malty finish. Excellent amber lager.
Birra molto equilibrato, bel colore, bella schiuma.profumi di miele di castagno, in bocca dissetante e pulita con un bellamaro alla fine.

Bottle from Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours light amber with a modest beige head and a bready aroma. There is a toasty malt flavor with a dry slightly bitter finish. This is a well-balanced brew that is easy to drink.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2013 Bottle pours orange gold with white head. Aromas of funky apple juice, light caramel, and malty bread. The taste is similar with a musty German lager flair and a very smooth finish. Full and hearty, this makes American lagers look puny. On tap it is much more floral and deep, with an added amount of spice from the grain. Very delicious, and very quafable.

500ml bottle
Aroma: fruity, malty-honey
Appearance: clear amber/toffee, stable white head
Taste: malty-grain,sweet breads, honey, slight fruitiness
Palate: lively, dry finish
Overall: this is a fantastic lager, I surprised myself with the score I gave it, I can easily quaff liters of this beer
Nice floral hop aroma. Pleasant mouth feel with high carbonation. Malty flavor with a lite honey sweetness. I really enjoy this beer.

Single bottle purchased from a Co-op Liqour Store on 12/27/2011. Colour: Light brown and orange with medium white head. Nose: Grassy hops, light caramlled malt, spring vegetation, white pepper. Taste: Medium sweet, mediumbitter, medium-light sour. Huge grain, lots of caramlaized barley, spiced citru s. A solid bitter grip late. This is extremely well crafted and just plain great beer.

500 ml bottle into pint glass, no bottle dating.  Pours hazy golden orange color with a nice 2 finger fairly dense off white head with good retention that reduces to a thin cap.  Some spotty lacing on the glass as well.  Aromas of big bready malts, caramel, herbal spiciness, toasted malt, and light apricot fruitiness.  Classic Oktoberfest aromas, very nice stuff.  Taste of caramel, toffee, biscuit, herbal spiciness, toasted malt, and light fruitiness.  No bitterness present; with lingering notes of caramel, toasted malt, biscuit, and herbal spices on the finish for a bit.  Great flavor balance and maltiness; with absolutely no cloying sweetness.  Medium carbonation and body; with a slightly creamy and smooth mouthfeel.  Alcohol is extremely well hidden with hardly any noticed at all.  Extremely drinkable and smooth as expected for the style.  Overall this is a great Oktoberfest and one of the best I have had yet.  Great balance and great malt flavor.

500ml bottle from the state store 
Appearance: Clear golden with a big foamy white head and good lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, toffee, fruity and sugar 
Taste: Toasted malts, caramel, yeast with a bitter finish 
A nice Oktoberfest.

Pint glass....nice pillowy head with a decent amount of carbination. Golden amber color with aroma of roasted malts. Taste is smooth, medium to light body, slight hoppiness with a tinge of alcohol burn on the finish. Not too bad on the palate and wallet.

Pours a deep golden amber with a nice white handead and good lacing. Nose of lightly roasted caramel malts with floral hops  Medium in body and very smooth in mouthfeel The flavor is dominated by the caramel malt sweetness and the finish shows lots  of the floral hops. There is a delightful flora spicy nuance at the end.  Very nice rendition of the style.

My Bottom Line :  
Honeyed and toasted cereals reign within this Festbiers rich yet quaffable mouthfeel, building a textbook example of this type of lager.

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-A veil of foam floats atop the pale amber shine.
-The finish is a tad shallow for my tastes (mostly sweetness and shy on the spicy hop bitterness). 
-Malts also develop bread-like flavors.
-This is as pleasant (and linear) as most Oktoberfests Ive had from Bavaria. Just not a huge fan of this type of lager (too sweet and predictable).

Bottle.

Rich amber/gold color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, caramel, & light floral hops; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, caramel, hops, some toffee, and spice; Nicely balanced; One of the better Oktoberfest brews.
Another one of my favorites for the Autumn season, has some nice pumpkin notes but it seemed a little lighter the second time I had it. Will have to try it again next year.

Classic example of this style in every way.  Makes me wonder if it is the one all others try to copy.  Very malty nose, with floral elements and apple.  Very sweet palate, with a subtle woodsiness and a bit of grain.  Light orange/dark gold, nice lacing.  Rock solid.

I find this beer to be lightly sweet and a little bit malty. I did not find the aroma to be near as good as the tase!!

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2012 i love this brew and look forward to seeing it every autumn. Pours a beautiful golden/copper color with a great head. Malty and bready but not sweet, just as a great fest beer should be. Finishes clean. This is my favorite Oktoberfest beer!

Draught in Munich.

Head is mostly lasting.
Body is medium amber.

Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain, caramel), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers), with a light note of DMS.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately bitter, slightly unclean.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Decent enough balance, but quite dull and not particularly clean.Earlier Rating: 10/16/2002 Total Score: 3Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Ok but nothing special.  Fairly sweet without much to balance.  Simple aroma.
This is a true German oktoberfest. Very smooth and malty with a good sweet flavor and finish.

Light amber color with a good long-lasting head and full-glass lacing.  A light roasted malt taste balanced well with floral hops.  Not overpowering, but better with each gulp (big swallows bring out the flavor).  Solid session beer for an outdoor garden on a sunny autumn afternoon.  Ayinger never fails - another winner.
WOW...  This is one of the best beers Ive ever tried.  Color and appearance are average for the german brew but he taste is off the charts!  Helps that I love these Bavarian wheat beers!!!

Bottle from Trader Joe.

Poured a brilliant, crystal-clear copper. Nice pillowy head and good lacing. Smelled sweet malt, caramel and biscuit. Body is lighter than expected and carbonation is higher than expected, but this is a very malty beer nonetheless. It has a faintly astringent/cloyingly sweet aftertaste at first, but I got used to it quickly.

Good beer.

Somewhat disappointing considering this breweries reputationEarlier Rating: 8/6/2007 Total Score: 3.3On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Amberish color with sweet malty aroma. Sweet malty taste. medium bodied. pretty good

This beer pours a beautiful fall colored amber with a surprisingly active head.  Aroma is pretty flat, with a faint sweet caramel malt being the only discernible note.  Hopefully this is only from the bottle I acquired. Anyways...the taste is much much better.  Notes of bread, malt, caramel, slight sweet sugar with a fantastic balance and palate that make this an absolutely drinkable beer.  Wonderful Oktoberfest, perfect interpretation of the style

Bottle. The pour was a light clear amber with a huge (3-4 finger) white foamy head that had good retention and fairly good lacing.

The aroma was very light and mild of a toasted biscuit malt, a mild floral hop and a light doughy yeast with a hint of caramel.

The taste had an extremely light sweet malty presence from the start and finished about the same with a nice note of caramel at the end. The flavor was left hanging around for a nice long while after the swallow.

Mouthfeel was surprisingly light in body and watery in texture with a fizzy carbonation.

Overall an Oktoberfest that is super light in body and flavor. Although a tasty brew it could have used a little more of both.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2016 I have generally been fond of this brewer but this beer was underwhelming. +++ Sampled on draft at 3R6P this beer poured a dark orange-caramel color with a medium sized foamy tan head that faded and left no lacing. The aroma was sweet and tangy iced tea. The flavor was tangy and sour malts with nut and light ripe fruit undertones. Medium finish and body. Disappointing.

(Draught at Bishops Arms Folkungagatan, Stockholm, 21 Oct 2011) Amber colour with frothy, white head. Malty, slightly roasted nose with caramel, toast, crisp-bread and orange peel. Malty taste with notes of dark bread, toast, raisins and a mild, spicy bitterness in the finish. Medium body, with rounded mouthfeel. A certain malt sweetness throughout. Well balanced and tasty. Nice one.

Draught at Far i hatten.
Clear amber coloured with a small white head.
Malty aroma of hay and caramel with notes of hops.
Malty flavour of hay and caramel with notes of hops.
Hoppy finish.Earlier Rating: 7/2/2007 Total Score: 3.1Bottle.
Hazy orange coloured with a white ehad.
Malty aroma of caramel, rye bread and fruits.
Flavour of caramel, rye bread and fruits.

Draft. A dark golden beer with a beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with nootes of malt and caramel, leading to dry finish.Earlier Rating: 6/30/2007 Total Score: 2.9Bottled. A hazy orange beer with a thin orange head. The aroma is sweet citrusy combined with notes of caramel, and so is the flavor, leading to a slightly bitter finish.

I poured a 500ml bottle into an Oktoberfest mug.Appearance: Attractive shade of orange/copper. Virtually no carbonation visible. Forms a large, white, sudsy head which laces and retains fairly well.Smell: Very generic lager aroma with light indication of sourness (nothing in the realm of Heineken, just a little off). Slightly sweet, a faint floral note but not very pungent overall.Taste: Its not just big deal beers that have hype or a reputation to live up to, sometimes something fairly innocuous can precede itself as in the case of Ayinger Oktober Fest-Märzen. Ive heard this is the best Oktoberfest beer from Germany so I definitely wanted to try it. But after the first swig, I failed to see what was so impressive about it.The initial taste is a light confectionary sweetness right away. Toffee and lollipop flavors hit and leave a lingering sweet aftertaste on the tip of the tongue and lips. It then gives way to a very generic, but inoffensive, amber lager palate. Theres sharp bitterness through the middle, accompanied by dry biscuity malt flavors. The finish is very mild leaving an almost completely clean aftertaste. Nothing about the palate here particularly impresses me, but nothing turns me off, either. Its better than most German lagers I can recall, but wasnt the syrup bomb I was expecting it to be. Mouthfeel: Thin, tepid, wet, cold, clean.Drinkability: Mild palates and thin, clean mouthfeels almost always make for highly drinkable beers and Ayinger Oktober Fest-Märzen is no exception. The thin, tepid texture makes it go down very smooth and the body feels much lighter than its 5.8% ABV would seem to indicate. An ideal beer for a feast or any kind of session scenario.

Pleasant aroma.  Slight malt, sugar, bread and nut aroma - but subtle and well blended.  Pours deep golden near amber, with little or no lingering head.  Taste has a subtle buttered pretzel note to it. Round edges with a feignt floral tone.  Nice beer.
Mildly sweet floral aroma. A beautiful clear amber color.  Soft sweet with a mild bitterness with a smooth dry finish. A pleasure to consume.

poured from a 500mL into a stein. Pours a solid orange color with a decent head

very good and classic oktoberfest aromas of malts, grains, and a bit of spice along with blood oranges

medium bodied with a good feel, but one that is lacking a bit on the mid-palate. Very malt based with some blood oranges

Im a real fan of this oktoberfest. One of my favorite oktoberfest beers. Well balanced and brings everything that an oktoberfest beer should
Bronze color with medium head and body. Modest carmel aroma and taste. Little hop bitterness. A relatively bland brew.
Light, malty, crisp.  Very sessionable.  I could use more malt but it lives up to its style and I would recommend it.

A delightful beverage. Malty sweetness with a hint of caramel in the aroma. The warm, amber color is very inviting as is the lively carbonation, and the mildly sweet taste is very subtle and superior to many others of this style. The sweetness carries through to the long finish. Well worth sorting through the rows of seasonal beverages to find this one.

500ml bottle poured a pale amber color with some orange highlights and a big off-white head that generated some nice lacing.  Aroma is caramel and lightly toasted malts with some lovely floral hops.  Taste is moderate malty sweetness and a dry hoppy finish.  Nice carbonation and a light to medium body give this beer a nice mouthfeel and I highly recommend this beer to anyone as it is fairly easy to drink.
Thick frothy head.  Sweet cinnamon aroma, a little bit of hay.  Amber color.  Mild carbonation.  Rather dry as advertised.  Very smooth and drinkable.
pours slightly dark golden color. very malty aroma, slightly roasted malt scent. deep tastes of colorful malts with a slight sweetness

Pour from a 500ml bottle. Clear deep yellow brew with small white head. Aroma of malt and a little floral hops. Taste is nice light malt at the start transitioning to a dry finish. Average palate. Very tasty.

500 ml bottle. Pours a clear dark orange. Aroma of citrus, grain, toffee, vanilla and strawberry. Flavor is citrus, grain, toffee. Slightly sweet finish.  Extremely easy drinking. One of the best (if not THE best) Oktoberfest beers.

Ar: Light cracker malt, a touch of spicy hops.
Ap: Clear orange-gold - large off-white head with excellent retention and a thick layer of lacing.
T: Crisp cracker maltiness up front with some sulfur - turns into a firm toasted maltiness with spicy hop accent - light but firm bitterness at finish - extremely clean and refreshing.
P: Medium-light body with high carbonation - finish is dry.
O: Supremely drinkable with a beautiful depth of malt flavor that does not pass into bock territory - satisfying, clean - I could drink this by the liter.

Pale copper hue.  Mostly malty in the nsoe with some metallic scent.  Maybe from the cap?  Bready.  Medium mouthfeel and the smells of breadiness and maltiness are reinforced in the taste.  More substance.  Prettty enjoyable.
Bottle.  Gold pour.  Big head that recedes quickly.  Aroma of apple juice.  Taste is really grassy, with some bitterness, and notes of honey.  Heavy carbonation.  Crisp clean lager taste.

Poured from a 500 ml bottle to a SS tulip pint glass.2 finger head diminishing to a nice layer of creamy foam with some lacing.Aroma of sweet grain maltyness and a hint of fruit/floral hops,fresh refreshing clean pleasant aroma.Real foamy creamy start from this orange light copper beer prettty well carbonated  light carmel vanilla candy like with some sweet grain/breadiness fading into a very crisp short tartness then to some carmelmalt very soft kinda dry bittering that is very mellow and smooth, with hints of iron,mineral or that metallic like taste i get in a lot of marzens it seems but is small compared to the good light sweet carmely/creamy taste.
 Not super familiar with this beer but have had many i enjoy from ayinger and it seems this is a pretty good example of a good classic oktoberfest.

Sweet malt forward. Appearance is golden apricot. Clear smal head, large bubbles. Taste is malt forward with a hint of aroma hops finished with a trace of bitterness. Bit of honey. Palate is crisp and refreshing. Overall one of the best beers I have ever had. Close to perfection.

This Oktoberfest has a somewhat mellow yeast aroma that seems slightly subdued, but with a hint of sourdough. It has clean orange-amber color, a medium head, and good lacing. The hops hit you first with their bitterness and from the mid palate on it transforms into this smooth, malty, welcoming, earthiness. The caramel flavors I usually get with Oktoberfests is minimal. A "feel good" beer. This one is awesome with some interesting character.
Im not usually a fan of beers that feature malt over hops, but this one is different.  Nice hop bitterness, but the malt has main stage.  I really enjoyed the sweetness of the malt.

On tap. A clear orange-amber colour with a high, creamy, beige head. An aroma of malt, bread, hay, caramel and hops. The taste is medium sweet. A medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation and a medium long finish
Fantastic oktober fest, extremely crisp and drinkable. Malts shine strong. I love it

[Tap] Pours a bright orange color with a cap of white head. Aroma of caramel malts, grains, light grass and dust. Grainy and malty taste includes biscuits, toasted bread, light nut and mild hops. Dry finish was a tad grainy. Decent mouthfeel, but not quite as good as some of the other Ayinger offerings. Prickly carbonation. Not bad overall. I was pleasantly surprised to find this on tap.Earlier Rating: 2/5/2007 Total Score: 3.6(Bottle) Pours a dark amber color with a nice, lasting white head. Sweet malts dominate this one, with some bread and toffee in the taste. A good, and highly drinkable beer, but not overly complex.

Poured from a 16.9 ounce bottle into an nonic pint glass.

Appearance: This one gushed out of the bottle as soon as it was cracked. Once I cleaned things up, it pours a honey gold with orange highlights and a 1-2 finger foamy off-white head. Minimal lacing.

Smell: Sweet German malt with sweet grains and a touch of spices. Very sweet aroma.

Taste: Sweet bready grains up front followed by lightly roasted malt in the middle before ending with a touch of earthy hops. The aftertaste is dry, earthy and just a little bitter.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a high amount of prickly carbonation. 

Drinkability: High drinkability. Goes down smooth and easy. I could knock back a few in the right situation.

Overall: Very good beer overall. One of the better Octoberfest beers on the market. Give it a shot.

Love this beer. It strikes the perfect balance between the drinkable but flat oktoberfests served on the wiesen, and the overly carmelly and sweet export oktoberfests that most breweries brew. It has a subdued yet complex malt sweetness but finishes light and clean. Not cloying. This is the archetype.

Orange yellow beer, white head. Aroma of biscuit, malts, cookies, sweetish, light caramel, spices, some marzipan and yeast. Flavour sweet malty, cookies, spicy, with a slight bitterness.
(Draught @ Ayinger Speis und Trank, where it is called Festbier)
On tap. Had this brew at Oktober Fest in Mt. Angel. Crisp and refreshing. Well balanced between sweet and hoppy. A bit more hoppy than I expected. Easy to drink.
Had several bottles of this in New Ulm, MN for Oktoberfest.  One of the best Marzen style beers Ive ever had. delicious.

What a Marzen. The pour is a bright copper with a thin white head and some light sparkly carbonation. The nose is of fresh floral hops with beautiful grass and light caramel maltiness. No alcohol on the nose. Overall, a sweet and hoppy nose. The middle is sweet and hoppy with a beautiful fresh and floral taste. The finish is pungent and thick with an overall refreshing finish and crisp taste. The body is oily and full bodied with a crispness that satisfies.
Smells of straw and malt.  Average appearance.  Good balanced taste.  Very smooth.

pours a copper color with a nice fluffy off white light tan head. aroma is a malty marzen aroma. flavor is the same as aroma but stronger with a little dry aftertaste. has some good lacing and is a little better than the kostrizer oct. i just had.

(bottle)   A great disappointment based on prior ratings.  My sample fell short in every category.  The sweet malt overcome by tart & bitter flavor with some skunk.  Perhaps an old bottle or poorly conditioned but among the bottom of this style for me.

The beer pours an orange-amber color with a large white head. The aroma is heavy on the nutty and toffee malts with a little bit of grass thrown in from the hops. The flavor is is full of toffee, caramel and biscuit malts. There are some nice floral hop notes in the flavor as well which really add to the flavor profile. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very easy to drink and one of the best German-brewed märzens out there.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2011 Bottle like the picture - 500ML.  Pleasantly luminescent, golden body under a dissolving, white head and a sticky lacing of fine, uniform bubbles.  Aroma is cereal, fruit blossom, with a hint of dough.  Brewers can probably smell the distinct hops.  Floral comes out more as it warms.  The aroma is of good beer.    Taste is mildly salty and carries the aroma well.  Palate is gentle, light, lively, classy, creamy, and without finish which is fine.
Ayinger represents the Oktober Fest-Marzen style very well.  This is suitable for session or fashionable entertainment.  Oom Pah Pah!

Poured bottle from Trader Joes into tulip glass. Brilliant, deep golden-orange color with big long-lasting white foam, very little lacing. Medium-bodied mouthfeel. Rich nutty and malty sweet taste but with a soft dry aftertaste from the toasted barley and sparkling carbonation. Subtle tangerine taste. Very clean lager fermentation with a faint bubble-gum yeast aroma as it warms. Mild bitterness and aroma of German noble hops. Ayinger Oktober Fest-Märzen is still brewed in strict accordance with the Reinheitsgebot, or "German Purity Law," and is an official beer of Munich Oktoberfest. Its easy to imagine drinking a huge stein of this delicious beer. Cool bottle and bottle cap design, this one has the whole aesthetic package. A prime example of the Oktoberfest/Märzen style.
Low aroma, clean crisp malt taste. Nothing wrong with it, but Im not used to lagers, which now taste simple after drinking so many ales.

Draft at ncbc. Pours a clear dark gold. Loose sudsy white rim. Caramel and wet leaves on the nose. Creamy light body with soft carb. Toast, caramel, and a dark tangy fruitiness on the mid palate, kinda like grilled plums or something. Not that i have grilled a plum, ever. This is clearly the king of the oktoberfest hill, because plenty of others try and fail to get a similar note. Mild toasty finish. It is for sure a harvest beer, begging to be served with slow roast pork.
Everything was ok. Aroma - a little weak, appearance - again ok, taste - nothing special. Average at best
Old Bank, Turku. Dark amber body, lasting white head. Clearly malty nose. Grainy malty tase sweet, not too sweet or complex, but cool nuff.  Herbal noted, Ok, tasty, not memorable.

Draught at Haket. 
Crystal clear deep golden colour with persistent white head. Bready malty nose, pretty clean and laid back, not much to write home about but solid. The flavour is bready and malty and leans towards citrus. The maltiness is poorer than expected, Ayinger beers are usually really clean malty. Body is light-medium and the bitterness is higher than expected. Bit old, stale feel to it all but still pretty solid beer.
I really didnt like the fruity smell of this beer. It wasnt bad but it was a little too sweet.
Pours a reddish orange. Thin head. Aroma is candy sweet. Light and easy to drink. Could use more malt body for me. Ends up too sugary.

The perfect Oktoberfest marzen and the original. Big malty nose with a slight noble hop balance. Pours a gorgeous copper capped with a thick rocky white head. Thick lacing. Malt forward but enough hops to keep it from being sweet. Thick pillowy mouthfeel. An excellent food beer.

Bottle. Poured into a DFH tulip glass a clear light copper color aith a slight bone white head. Sweet, bready nose with some caramel. Medium mouthfee. Sweet start with a nice malty backbone. Biscuity. Honey. Medium mouthfeel. Ever so slight bitterness built in. Pretty nice. Some lace.

Nose is huge amounts of caramel and bread. This oktoberfest has some life to it already. Pours a clear bronze color that looks damn nice in a huge ass glass. Tastes like caramel malts and some straw/bread notes. Slight hop finish that keeps you coming back for more. Excellent!!

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Tap. Clear light gold pour with a small frothy white head. Sweet nose with some bread. Smooth palate. Taste is lightly toasted bread, light lemon, and a touch of caramel. Really good stuff.
UPDATED: SEP 28, 2011 Tap. A light caramel color. Very smooth with a hint of fruit.  One of my favorite Oktoberfest beers so far!
Coppery amber in color with a foamy tan head. Crisp and balanced with a malty base and hints of bitterness in the finish. Very nice.
Very crisp, rich aroma. Pours gold with medium head, has a toasted taste with moderate carbonation. Mild hop flavor with woody hints. Very tasty Oktoberfest. One of my favorites.

Poured a light honey color with a large white foamy head.  Aroma is quite malty with apples and sweet fruit.  Slightly skunky.  Taste is very smooth and sweet with lots of light fruit and grains.  Very drinkable and well balanced, not too sweet.  Finish is nice and crisp.  Great Oktoberfest!

This is a very drinkable Marzen.  It pours copper with a nice white head and has a very nice roasted malt flavor to it.  Id highly recommend.  Its probably my favorite of the German Oktoberfest beers Ive had so far this year.

Draft @ Bishops Arms Gustav, Malmö. Pours a clear Golden color with a longlasting white head. Has a fruity grainy weak grassy aroma. Fruity malty grainy weak grassy flavor. Has a fruity malty grainy grassy finish.
Tap. Pours with minimal foam. Dark gold color. Typical german octoberfest beer, but not bad either.

500ml bottle from Trader Joes. Poured a mostly clear orange color with a off-white head. Aroma was biscuit, slight spice, solid malts. Flavor was a touch grassy, with caramel, malts. Inexpensive and drinkable.

On tap at Flying Saucer-Cordova.  Somewhat light pour. The floral notes are quite prominent. I drank this in a session with other Oktoberfests and it offered the most complex flavors and was probably the most well-executed of the beers I had even though I prefer the more classic flavor of Spaten.
pours an amber color with a malty aroma.  A slight bitterness in the taste, with a floral finish.  This beer was okay for a Marzen, I was excited by its appearance but was let down by its taste.

Wow, this one did not disappoint.  Brilliant pristine appearance met by a nice sweet yet refreshing nose.  Are those apricots...?  The taste is malty enough to drive the flavor, but not so overpowering that you get to taste how clean the beer really is.  It is the benchmark for me in Octoberfests/Marzens.

500ml bottle - Pours clear amber with a massive fluffy light tan head. Smells caramelly sweet, tons of bready malt with a slight floral hop presence. Taste is roughly the same, with smooth grain and a caramelly sweet finish that fades into a mineral note. Smooth and well-carbonated, and balanced in all aspects. I dont love Oktoberfests, but I love this beer.
Lite orange-copper and white head.  Bready, burnt toast, and citrus aroma and flavour.  Syrupy with mild bitter finish.

On tap, poured orange with slightly off white head.  Aroma had notes of some grass, pine, moving into some biscuit and very slight spice note.  Taste was a bit watered down, but had notes of grass, biscuit, some slight caramel and spice, finishing slightly bitter.  Needed more maltiness for the style, but wasnt bad.

500ml bottle.

Pours crystal clear golden amber with a ton of bubbles streaming up from the bottle feeding a thick, fluffy head.

Aroma is crisp clean bready malts, caramel and floral hops.  There is some light spiciness as well but the overall character is crisp, clean and malty.

The taste is excellent and maybe a tad sweeter than the nose suggests.  There is more caramel and a hint of fruit, pears possibly.  There is also a hefty toasted bread backbone.

The mouthfeel is one of the best Ive had for this style.  So creamy and smooth, much more than any American Oktoberfest Ive tasted.

Ive always been enamoured with Celebrator so I guess I shouldnt be surprised that this is one of the better Oktoberfests in the world.  Perfect beer for the season.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2013 Deep gold, bubbly carbonation and tall white head. Spicy-malt aroma. Taste is rich and malty; one of the richest Marzenâs Iâve found. Notes of caramel, bread dough and earthy-toasted malt. I can see why this is the top-rated Marzen. This is the best Iâve had.

500ml bottle from Picks poured into a Lager glass. Pours an orange/gold with huge head, about 3 fingers. Aroma of floral hops and sweet butterscotch malt. Taste is light sweet. Medium bodied with a thick and creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long slightly bitter finish. Overall, very good. Something I would drink again.

Transparent brownish orange pour, with a mid-size (quickly dissipating) head. Slightly tinny malts on the nose. Something like buttery brown sugar - a smell reminiscent of the Thanksgiving dinner table. Full-bodied, but with a dilute flavor, that has odd hops and a slightly metallic note. Not nearly enough malty sweetness - this really needs a stronger flavor. Ingredients, anyone?

On draught at Winking Lizard. This brew pours a clear amber-copper color with a medium foamy white head that dissipates steadily to a film. Aroma of toasted malt, caramel and hops. Medium body with flavors of sweet caramel malt, grain, hops and yeast. The finish is malty and sweet with a light grassy hops aftertaste. Above average overall.Earlier Rating: 9/7/2003 Total Score: 3.7On draught at the Winking Lizard Tavern in Columbus, OH. This beer is a hazy bright amber color with a medium off-white head and nice lacing. The aroma is a fair amount of malt along with a bit of hops. Medium-bodied with a lot of malt from the get-go. The beer does seem to get a little spicier and hoppier toward the end of the glass. The finish is light and a little hoppy. This is a good seasonal from Ayinger.

NBD, NY 500ml ($4.75): Pours a light amber colour with a very loose head. Aroma is strong malts,and while it is still cold there is some of that distinct German lager smell. The taste is very full. There is no gap. Personally, I think that as it warms up, it gets to be a substantially better beer. Awesome malt flavor. Very mild hops, but they do leave a bit of an aftertaste. Hop character is pretty nice; I see why they would call it floral. Balance is pretty great. Really good beer, but it only really shines when it gets to the right temperature, and then it is a powerhouse.

pours clear orange with a thin white head and a bit of lacing.  aroma is oranges and spice.  body is good for a marzen, taste is pale malt, with a bit of sweet orange peel.  finish is dank... characteristically lagerish.
It poured a hazy burnt orange color with a small white head. The aroma was of apple, roasted malt, caramel, honey, and mild lemon. The taste was of malt and a soft finish.  A decent Oktoberfest.
Large bottle.  Golden color, clear, white frothy head... Pours great. Aroma has hints of honey with malt.  Highly carbonated but a fuller body.  A little sweet and satisfying.  A very food beer.
Bottle.  Pours a beautiful clear orange with white head.  Aroma is caramel and straw.  Flavor is more of the same with a long sweet finish.  Very nice.
Great balance of spice, malt and hops.  Solid Oktoberfest beer from the always reliable Ayinger.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2012 Bottle --> big ol dimpled mug. The body on this one is quite attractive! FULL of bubbles with an orange pumpkin hue... and the head is epic. Scents of nutmeg, yeast and spices with a subtle hop twang - very festive and a tease to the tongue. The flavor is fresh and smooth, sweet malts and dried tangerine notes are enticing with a mellow and semi-dry finish. This beer is the image of Oktoberfest and a solid example of a damn good beer.

Good tasting Oktoberfest.  This is the first time I had this beer.  Bottle from market district in Robinson.  Pours golden color, aroma of floral hops and malts, smooth drinking beer.  Medium body, balanced, dry finish.  This one is definitely worth the try for Oktoberfest.

Poured into a tulip.  Huge head...a good 1.5".  Smells very sweet with honey and citrus.  Maybe even some butterscotch in there.  Perfect golden color.  Very well balanced....a little sweet and a little bitter.  Strong copper note...like I was sucking on a penny...but not in an overly bad way.
On tap at Frisco.  Amber color with white head.  Malt and hop aromas with hint of flowers.  Sweet caramel malt tast with hop finish and some spice.  One of my favorite Oktoberfests.

Pours perfectly clear copper-orange with fluffy, off-white head. Smells malty and kind of sweet with a touch of hops. Taste follows the nose, its good but nothing super outstanding, but probably the best of the style Ive ever had. Medium-bodied with a smooth, wet texture and decent mouth-carbonation, Ayinger Oktober Fest-Märzen finishes lightly crisp.

Poured from a bottle into a footed pilsner glass. Appearance is a hazy copper with a thick, bubbly, loosely packed head of foam. Aroma is grainy, sweet, and caramelly with just the slightest hint of hops. Taste is surprisingly light, but there is so much going on here that it remains complex and interesting. Sweet grains are in the forefront but give way to a smooth caramel middle and a slightly dry finish. Very light in body, but theres enough character here that you could easily sip it if you wanted to do so.

Appearance is very light amber with thin head and not much retention.  Aroma is cidery, light caramel malt, spicy noble hops.  Taste is spicy, lightly fruity, bready, caramelly.  Body is medium, avg carb, spicy finish.  Overall, kinda weak as far as oktoberfest beers go but still quite nice.

16 ounce pint - $6.75 at Taco Mac in Woodstock, Georgia.

Appearance: Arrived at my corner of the bar a hazed, amber-hued body with a slimming, bone white head.

Smell: Modestly sweet-scented toffee flecked toasted grains with an element of dark fruit as well as ripe orchard fruit.

Taste: Lightly grainy, lightly toasted sliced bread given a touch of sweet toffee candy. Fruitiness of golden raisins with more than a hint of apple peel. Small measure of yeastiness. Slightly steely, herbal hops with a subtle, balancing bitterness. Drying, malty finish with a continued accent of mild dried herbs.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium-plus carbonation.

Overall: Packs more punch than their Oktober Fest-Märzen, so, yeah, cant we just dump that brew in favor of this one? No rush, simply a suggestion. Its just something to think about, really.Earlier Rating: 6/10/2007 Total Score: 2.8Appearance: Served in an Ayinger glass, this beer pours a deep golden body with a frothy, off-white head. Very active bubbles. 

Smell: Light bready, toffee-scented aroma. Maybe some apples, too. 

Taste: Whoa, well, the malts are fairly played down flavor-wise. What remains is a restrained doughy flavor with a floral hoppiness. Noticeably more musty than other Oktoberfests.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Low carbonation - nearly flat. Slight alcohol warming comes through in the finish.

Drinkability: Not nearly as moving or stirring as some other Oktoberfests available.

Bomber to German beer glass my daughter brought me (She went to Germany without me).Light amber with medium white head that laces throughout the drink.  VA little banana and then some very delicate aromas--some floral hops, a little spice, cinnamon, Flavor is typically sweet with a nice quick dry bitter finish.  Very crisp, yet smooth in the mouth.  Very good for the style.
Draught @ Angleterre, Helsinki. Originally rated on 1.10.2010. Unbalanced, malty oktoberfest beer.

From notes.  Bottle purchased in Partenkirchen, at Fristo I think.  Pours amber, nice white head.  Malty, bready aroma.  Basically typical marzen flavors, toasty and malty, light caramel, subdued spicy hops.  Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle thanks to weihenweizen, pours a hazy orange/amber with a small white head, aroma is of spices with a hint of banana, the flavor has a nice fruity front with a malty middle and finish, pretty darn good.

Pours a beautiful amber with nice froth on top.  Smells grainy with slight Euro-funk underneath.  The taste starts sweet, heavy on buttery banana, then dries out in the middle, gaining a grain-laced nutty roastiness.  The finish stays slightly sweet, but the brisk carbonation limits what the flavors can achieve.  Decent, but too imported for my tastes.  (9/08)

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2011 Translucent copper with a foamy beige head, medium body with medium-high carbonation

Aroma: Lots of sweet toffee malt, floral and mildly citrusy hops, and some minerality.

Taste: sweet toffee malt, soft noble hop bitterness, and minerality.
Yummy goodness. Medium body with a light frothy head. Malty hint. Great beer

Poured out a mild looking clear amber brew with a foamy cap that needed some control to fill up my glass. Sticks to the rim and only leaves minimal early spots. The aroma is pleasant with plenty of grains that build the base for the fragrance, caramel, raisin, floral and more malts.... hint of orange? Pretty good taste - good enough to make this a multiple bottle drinker. Plenty of malts of grain, caramel and earth, light yet thick fruit, soothing well placed spices. This is a wonderfully easy to drink brew that has a smooth feel with ultra fine carbonation. The softness and tasty finish is very nice. Ayinger never disappoints.

light creamy soft mouth-feel with a slightly bitter finish. i get a kind of nutty caramel taste. a little earthy. hops bring a slight citrus flavor as well. its more subtle in taste and feel than some beers, but great aftertaste and overall well balanced beer, i.e. not too hoppy, but not flat.
niiice  amber pour w/med large head.  aroma of grassyness  taste was some malt nice mix of sweetness low grassy hops will have again.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2013 beautiful, clear amber pour from 500ml bottle - I quite enjoyed this Marzen.  Sweet, yeast, bread, and some champaign characteristics.  Top rated Marzen?  Why not, very enjoyable brew.**Not quite as impressed with this the third or fourth time around - .4 dev

Pours a light clear golden with a full white head that is gone rather quickly leaving behind no lacing to speak of.  This has a fairly significant amount of grass and lemon aromas to it fresh after the pour.  As it sits for a short spell, it takes on a nice sweet honey aroma and rich caramel malts.  Rather mild on the palatte, but yet not short of complexity.  Hay and citrus fruits are first noticeable and are quickly followed with honey.  the finish is a little short and light.

Bottle.
Golden amber pour with a good amount of white head.  One of the better Oktoberfest/Marzens out there - lots of bready malt aroma and flavor with a slight sweetness as well.  Wish they had this on tap at Addisons Oktoberfest.
Has a slight spice taste to it, otherwise a very bready, malty lager, a very good example of an Oktoberfest.

50 cL bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in a lager glass. Pours clear golden-amber with a tall, frothy off-white head. The head fades quickly to a small remnant and leaves minimal lace. The nose has aromas of grain, caramel malts, pear, banana and flowers. The flavour is somewhat sweet throughout, with notes of honey, toasted malts and fruit. There is a hint of floral hops, but malts remain dominant. The finish is moderate in length and quite grainy. On the palate, it is light-medium in body with a smooth, watery texture and lively carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice Märzenbier with big fruity notes and a soft malty character. A nice sessionable beer, but it could benefit from a bigger body. 2010-02-26

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2012 Ayinger is one of the few Germans that you cant get in the 12 oz variety of bottle. The cap is gimmicky and one of the coolest ones I have come across. No sign of freshness date, but I am pretty sure it is fresh.

Pours the lighter Oktoberfest style, the festival lager style, with a mix of amber and gold body. Nice 4 finger white head.

The malts smell juicy and roasted. The hops are earthy with a hint of spice, a nice scent to this one.

The mouthfeel is pretty full, a lot of sweetness, mostly malt, one of the heartier tasting Oktoberbests. The hop bitterness sneaks in slighlty at the end but it is well-balanced.

Overall a solid Oktoberfest beer, would like to have it by the 12 oz bottle though rather than the larger bottle. It is a well balanced entry into the field and may be what you want to try first if your pondering on which one to choose.

Had it again and I thought it was much hoppier and better, score bumped up.
Golden orange in color... Aroma of biscuits.... Flavor is caramel malts, light crisp hops... Pretty solid marzen
Nice golden lager with a thick white head.  Aroma of noble hops - nice crispy flavor - well balanced and very drinkable. Very tasty for the $3.50 I paid at the store - glad I bought two!

Bottle 50cl. A clear dark copper beer with good head. Smell is malty and caramel like. Aroma is nice on caramel and malty site quite sweet good body, bread and cereal notes, a nice beer with toasted notes. Hops character is low but beer is well done.
50 cl bottle. Pours amber with a white head. Aroma of grain, bread and caramel. Aroma is similar, with also malty notes. Medium body with medium carbonation.

Faint aroma of malts and citrus. Pours an expected amber, with one finger foamy offwhite head. Taste is very malty, with a nice bitter tinge from the hops to balance things out. Touches of caramel sweetness and grass accentuate the finish. Medium body, drinks smoothly with lively carbonation.

500 mL bottle. Thought I loved Sams Octoberfest, but it doesnt compare as far as flavor profile.  The depth of flavors in this Marzen is incredible.  Im ready to go to Germany now for the real deal.  Cant even describe in words.  Wish it was easier to find around here.  I had to order it through my bar and make it the beer of the month, but they ran out after I got my first and only case.  Will start earlier next year.

Pours a somewhat dark amber with an off white head. Tiny bits of lacing. Smell is slightly sweet with some caramel and a tiny bit of hoppiness coming through. Taste is similar, and is somewhat buoyed by a fairly thick mouthfeel. Not much alcohol presence on a medium body. Drikability is okay. Nothing is particularly wrong with the beer, but theres nothing to write home about either.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-18-2010
amber color. not much head and it doesnt last. aroma is bready and metallic. the taste is caramel and sweet malt, very subtle bitterness. creamy soft texture. overall too sweet for my taste.
Nice gold color and lots of bubbles. Within this style, this is an outstanding choice. Great flavor with a lot of body that can be sampled over and over.

Világos borostyán vörös színe van és olyan és igazán látszik rajta, hogy egy igazi szűretlen sörrel van dolgunk. Habja közepes méretű, tanyasi tojáshéjhoz hasonlatos színű és olyan krémes állagú, mint egy jófajta angol ale típusú sörnek. Illata karamellás, pörkölt mogyorós és enyhén malátás. Ezek az ízében is pompásan érezhetők, megtetézve egy jó adag német komlóval, ami egészen jó egyensúlyban van a többivel. Kissé vizes és enyhén szénsavas. Utóíze kissé fanyar és száraz, ami hosszan tart. Érdekes és igazán kellemes szomjoltó, pláne így a Márton napi libasült után.

On tap at Das Bierhas Burlington.
Appearance : clear pale amber with a med creamy head. Light lacing.

Aroma : slightly metallic with some raisins and light caramel. Nice malts and a bit of fruits.

Taste : Malt with light caramel and light raisins. Bready and quite tasty. Finsh rather dry and malty with notes of raisins and caramel.

Overall : Not so sure about the metallic nose. Nice raisins and caramel malt on taste. Enjoyalpe finish. Rather dry and drinkable. Clean taste but nose could be a bit cleaner (could be caused by the condition of the keg having been shipped oversea).
Nice caramel color with a nice oft-white head. Caramel notes on the nose and the palate. Tough style for me to rate, but i enjoyed the beer nonetheless, especially with knackwurst!

clear amber-straw color pours with foamy large and quickly diminishing head, aroma of metal and hay, nice mouthfeel, but somehow tastes flat, wondering if i got a bad bottle, hard to recommend off this tasting

Pours amber-orange with off-white head. Full nose of caramel and rich cereal malts. Full, sweet-ish palate reflects more caramel and brown sugar without being cloying. Hops add a light floral quality and balance out the palate. Excellent.

Bottle from my rip and run.  I was wondering from the point of purchase whether or not I had rated this in the past.  It seems to have slipped thru the cracks.  Pours a lovely medium pumpkin orange with an off white greasy looking head.  Nose of caramel malts. Surprise surprise, it tastes of sweet malts and light hops.  Medium bodied and sweet to the finish.  A nice Oktoberfest.

Clear amber gold with excellent lacing.  Aroma is yeasty, taste is thick and on the malty side.  A little bit watered down, not as appealing to me as Hacher-Pschorr or Paulaner.  Decent overall, will probably keep this one in the annual festbier rotation going forward.

Given to me by a friend and served from a bottle.  Amber color.  I thought it had kind of a sour smell to it, not unlike sour kraut.  Small whitish head and tasted slightly sweet.  Light and refreshing.

500 ml. bottle. 2010 batch.  It pours orange-gold with about two inches of puffy, long lasting head.  The aroma is is of sweet and roasted malts.  The body is creamy. The taste has a caramel sweetness, a roasted topping, and a pleasingly dry ending.  An enjoable Octoberfest beer.
Sampled in a big bottle. A really nice crisp marzen. Really liked it. It has very present but not overbearing hops and quality barley malts. Nice brew.

You cant go wrong with Ayinger!  Brought by Uncle Tom to a tasting with He, Uncle Steve, Brian the Beer Pimp, and the Wizard of Wort, Drbayern.  Poured a dark yellow, clear and clean.  The whiite head laced nicely.  The aroma was a nice European malty flavor.  Again the taste was European, somewhat musty and sweet.  The hops were minimal, but the bittering on the backside was nice.

Wow it pours a dense rocky head of fluffy white goodness.  Aroma is lager-like with a toasty and malty note.  Tastes of well-attenuated but malty and rich melanoidins.  Bread crust, toast, and a mature tobacco flavoring predominate.  Not as sweet or as underattenuated as some other oktoberfests....especially marzens.  Medium full body without the heavy brick feeling.  Very good.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2011 Rating that was on here was the wrong text....this is easily my fav octoberfest.  Light and refreshing with all the malty roasty flavors of an octoberfest but way more drinkable than just about any other marzen.  Very tasty and very drinkable.  I wish it was cheaper Id pound it all fall.

Dimpled mug for this guy.  First thing I notice about the beer is the clarity  its very clear.  The next thing I notice is the aroma, which I can smell from where Im sitting  my glass is about an arms length away.  Next we have the head, which is rocky, with inconsistent large and small bubbles.  As it fades, the head retention is strange.  It looks like fat suspended in broth  lets hope it doesnt taste like that.  Aroma reminds me a little bit of a farm, kind of like damp straw.  Damp leaves maybe.  Color is amber moving to gold, a little bit darker than a pumpkin.  Taste is light, with a slightly salt water mineral finish.  Mouthfeel isnt sticky, more along the lines of creamy.  Lager yeast is the name of the game here, as it dominates everything, from the nose of the beer into the first taste.  I expected this to have more malt characteristics, honestly, and they are there, to be sure, though not as sweet as I would like.  Instead hops are the focus, with some grassy dandelion hops lending a small amount of bitterness to the whole thing.  I find this beer strangely drinkable.  Its not like anything Ive had before  and thats always surprising.  Distinctive.

Draught. Pours clear amber with creamy white head. Taste is a bit muddied, sweetness and bitters. Palate has a full body, creamy, thick feel, average carbonation. Aroma has caramel, toast, herbs, bit of earthyness.
Pours a dirty gold with white head.  Aroma is malty, caramel, bread and some hoppy grass.  Taste is sweet with the caramel and bread coming together nicely.  Finish has some bitters  Solid

A rich, malty deep golden amber brew with medium body. Sweet, slightly nutty aroma. Flavor is lightly sweet and spicy. Clean, buttery finish. A very solid brew, but perhaps I prefer a bit more roastiness in my fest.

Light golden pour with a slight amber tint. No memorable head so to speak of. Dirty mineral and grain aroma. Taste is pure sweet maple sugar nutty sweetness. Not good for a beer unless youre attempting to drink your desert. Having said that, is it good? Yes. Its German beer for fucks sake, and with a capital "g" this time. Do they know how to fuck up beer even if they wanted to? Not if the Czechs are involved! A healthy dose of hops crushes the sweet shit on the finish in this beer and once again hops are the redeemer. Drink up me hearties, Yo Prosit!

Bottle @ Goodbar Beer Club.  Nose is some nice light caramel maltines, grassy hay-like malt, lightly spicy hops.  Flavor is light caramel, spritzey carbonation, grassy hops.  Finish is a bit sweet with floral hoppiness.  Nice but nearly cloying.
Fluffy head, dark golden color. Very well balanced. Roast malt and just enough hops and bitterness. Not too sweet.

On draft at coffee district. Big full orange gold color with a good amount of foam too boot. From the first sip you get a good amount of malt flavor swiftly followed by hops. The carbonation was very impressive as was the head retention. A very impressive octoberfest beer.
500mL bottle, pours golden amber with a white head. Aroma of grains, sweet malt and some floral hops. Flavour is pretty much the same - solid.

Crystal clear golden/tan.   Good malty aroma like a good German lager.  Smooth caramel and light yeasty flavor with a good roastiness which is noticable compared to other Oktoberfest beers.   Good hop bite to counter this that leaves just enough bitterness behind to make this satisfying and wanting another gulp.  Happy Oktoberfest everyone!!
500ml bottle-A dark gold pour-white head-aroma and taste of floral, spice,nice and malty with a sweet but dry finish

Pours a light orange color with a white head.Got the aroma of bread and malts.The flavor is a nice mild malty sweetness balanced by a nice bitterness.Got sweet aftertaste and goes down real smooth.Overall the best oktoberfest/marzen Ive ever had.
Bottled. Orange orange with thin white head. Aroma is lightly spiced and peppered pasta with a zesty citrus. Flavor is bitter and not too sweet. A real easy beer on a colder October day.

On tap from Aying, Germany. Was ecstatic to try this seasonal considering my like of their other beers. Hazy amber brown color, with a nice head. More hoppiness than expected and also a tad bitter. Was slightly disappointed in this Ayinger offering, even though it is still a nice beer

Pours a clear honey orange with very thin white frothy head that dissipates very quickly. Aroma is a mix of almond, honey and bread. Flavor is definite notes of honey, bread, cereal and floral flavors. Body is light with active carbonation.

Clear golden color right out of the bottle, with a modest head and nose  isnt there supposed to be a fine German malt aroma? There are overtones of toffee in the medium-bodied beer but these are just as mild; the clean lager taste is quite dry with a bitter aftereffect. Carbonation is high. Doesnt match its reputation.

Pours a medium golden amber, with a large foamy head.  The off-white head still persisted during the session.  The aroma is upfront, with toasted malts and some slight hoppiness.  Taste is also strong and largely relfects the aroma--a mild toasted malt flavor is front and center, with some bready, slightly grassy qualities.  Hoppiness imparts a little bitterness but is definitely in the background.  Mouthfeel is average.  In all, a fine Oktoberfest beer if flavor is high on the list of priorities.
Bottle: Pours amber with a medium head.  Typical Oktoberfest beer. Nice smooth finish.

Tap at Paradiso Dupont. Pours a clear, light amber with a fizzy, small creme to yellow head. Little retention. No lace. Aroma of candy corn and toffee. Taste is super malty and toffee froward. Sweet, chewy orange candies and candy corn abound moving to an astringent palate. Meh.

500 ml bottle at The Royale on their Tuesday Oktoberfest celebration night.  Pours a somewhat cloudy golden color with a thick, foamy eggshell white head.  Notes of grains, honey, Munich malts, red apple skins, straw, grass, dust, and nuts.  Light-medium bodied, with soft but plentiful carbonation and a straw mouthfeel.  This is a very nice Oktoberfest beer, a good traditional example of the style.

Draught. Deep amber clear colour, beige looking medium head, ok lacing. Aroma of toasted malt, caramel and some hops. Good mouthfeel. Flavour has some sweetness with topasted malt and caramel along with some bitterness.
Roasty, floral, basement aromas.  Has a clear amber and orange color.  Minimal head.  Light bitter aftertaste.  Good October Fest beer but in my opinion not worthy of the ratings on this site.
Bottle.  Pours a orange gold with a white head.  Not as sweet as the ones Im used to, but one of the best Ive ever had.  Malty, but with a nice backbone.  Very good example of the style.
UPDATED: SEP 18, 2013 Pours amber with white head and no lacing.  Aroma of bread and carmel malts.  Taste is absent any hops, lots of sweet malts.  Medium-bodied, rich, and slick.

Draught at ølbaren. 
Clear dark amber - offwhite head. 
Roasted. Ryebread. Caramel. Light nutty. Light hoppy. Nice dryness. Nice.
Bottle.  Best Oktoberfest Ive had to date.  Velvety, amber appearance.  Perfect balance of malts and hops.  Medium bodied and silky smooth.  I served it with a bacon mac-n-cheese at a pairing event.

17oz bottle from Joes.  Love the decorative cap.

Deep orange/golden color. Very clear and highly carbonated.  Nice tan head that dissipated quickly.  Sweet caramel malt aroma.  Honey and caramel malt on the flavor, with biscuit and toffee.  A bit of earthy hops as well.  Crisp, clean.  Very nice märzen...

Pours clear gold, foamy white head. Aroma of grain, honey, some apple and nut, kind of smells like a farm if that makes any sense, not in a funk sense but just outdoors. Taste is very delicate, lots of bready malt, hay, some nut, some sweet fruit. Im not a huge fan of Ofests but this is definitely a great beer and I enjoy it a lot. I think what sets this apart from others is that it has more floral characteristics , and without being bitter. Very smooth.
Pours a golden amber with a white head. Aroma is sweet caramel,bready notes, and grassy hop. Flavor is toasty caramel malt, lightly grainy, with a hint of hops and a clean finish.
Nose of weak hops, dough, and umami. Mediumheavy feel and wellrounded carb. Taste is gingerbread, sweet fruits, late yeast

Bottle poured into glass mug. golden ruddy orange with little to no head. not surprising for an oktoberfest. light malty aroma. Has a hint of sweetness. Medium-light body and a dry finish. This is a very refreshing and drinkable beer.
