Hazy orange with a large off white head. Aroma was yesty with toasted malt and hints of caramel. Flavor had toasted malt, caramel and yeast. Finished sweet.

Strictly the toasted grain aroma,maybe a hint of caramel ,taste is light grain and that slight sweet caramel sweetness,flavors while appreciatively mellow,not expressive enough in taste, just a bit above ordinary. Isuppose it tastes better in Germany

On tap at McNellies OKC.  Pours a clear gold color. Thin white head that dissipates to a small ring. Aroma is caramel malt and clover honey. Flavor is similar, with additional notes of apple cider. Medium mouthfeel and nice clean finish. Excellent for the style.

500 ml Bottle. Courtesy of liveFREEorRYE.  Hazy amber body with a large, frothy, off-white head, that lasted awhile. Aroma is mostly malty with strong notes of sweet caramel and lighter notes of toasted bread, flowers and peach. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately bitter and lightly acidic. Medium body with a creamy texture and lively carbonation. Oktober fest isnt my favor brew at all, but this should be higher end for the style.
Nice, golden-amber color.  Malty nose and a similar taste.  Very crisp finish.  I could drink liters of this stuff while sitting in a tent with thousands of sweaty drunk people for sure.
Bottle. Aromas of clean malts and wheat. Taste is copper and tin like. Some light malts and not much else. Boring.

Bottle from whole foods. Pours clear amber with two-finger head that quickly subsides to a thin skiff of bubbles. Sweet aroma of caramel, grains, and some mild floral notes. Malty flavor with the same kind of sweetness promised by the aroma, and a slight hops tingle. Clean and well balanced, lively texture on the tongue, lingering finish that reveals more grassy hops flavor. A pleasant beer.
UPDATED: JAN 27, 2015 A very good Oktoberfest beer. Malty but not too much, easy drinking but not bland. Lovely stuff. Serving: Bottle
Golden with pillowy white head and Munich malt aroma. Malt forward with toasty nose and balancing hops. Clean lager finish. Almost creamy mouthfeel smooths then dries.

On tap at Gingerman Houston:  Color is a nice copper orange.  Weak malt aroma with a touch of spice.  Flavor is very similar as it has some cinnamon and clove present but its hard to detect.  Overall, Im kinda disappointed... this is supposed to be the best Marzen?  Ill have to try again as maybe this is an aberration.

The flavor brings strong carmel and some hints of toffee. As the beer warms you get molasses that seems to carry right through to the end. Some grassy notes too.

When it comes to the aroma some good malt,carmel and a little grassy notes

Pours a copper color a quick disappearing white head. It has a nice amount of carbonation

The beer finishes  with solid grassy hops and spiciness. But there is a sweetness from some molasses  that tends to linger on the palate.  Its a good version of the style with there own twist. I could never do a full session of these but still enjoyable. But another good beer from these guys.

Golden amber in color with a pale tan head that disappears quickly.  Aroma of toasted pecans and pumpkin, very evocative of fall.  Flavor is smooth and malty, mostly caramel and nuts with a bit of banana and vanilla.  Lingering earthy palate, very nice finish. Tasty autumn beer.
500mL Bottle -- Pours hazy burnt orange with a small white head.  Aromas of apple butter, roasted malt, quince paste, caramel, honey, and mild lemon.  Malty and off dry with a soft finish.

Bottle. Coppery golden color in appearance with an inch of pillowy white head. The aroma is cereal malt, lemon citrus and toffee. The taste begins with a blend of caramel, honey and nutty malt flavors followed by butterscotch and banana bread. The mouthfeel is crisp and clean with medium carbonation and a dry, malty finish. The overall flavor is light and malty without being overly sweet or too grainy. Seems like the ideal beer for an Oktoberfest celebration.

Appearance:  amber/orange gold, with a fluffy white head and extensive lacing.  Aroma:  malty, sweet and slightly earthy.  Taste:  malty, caramel sweetness and slightly earthy/spicy hops.  Finish:  short, clean and crisp.  Notes:  Wonderful oktoberfest brew. Absolutely delicious, perfectly drinkable, great flavors, beautiful pour.  Slightly more rich in the mouth than traditional lagers.  Ayinger simply does not make a bad beer.
On tap at Bruuveri, Helsinki. A bit on the amber side of the color spectrum, good size head. Great malty sweetness, the palate is in balance  as well. A great Festbier.

Bottle to pint glass.  Pours an orangish copper color with a tall and only slightly off-white head.  Great malty aroma--fruity, nutty, woody, lager yeast, and vanilla.  The flavor is pretty similar, with perhaps a hint of spiciness.  No alcohol whatsoever.  Medium body and carbonation.  Overall: as expected, spot on style.  Super delicious, very drinkable, and one of the few beers Ive had that is legitimately thirst quenching for me.

Bottle.  Pours a clear gold with a white head.  Sweet roasty malts are prevalent in the aroma.  This had a light to medium sweetness, medium body, and thick texture that had a very thirst quenching attribute.  Overall, this was a very enjoyable beer that I could recommend to any lager lover!
Draught.  Light brown pour with thick white head. Medium floral aroma.  Medium body, less malty flavour than some other festbiers.  Crisp finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle. Amber gold with quickly disappearing head. Aromas of caramel and roses. Sweet taste, yeast, slightly nutty finish.

On tap at restaurant.  Amber orange with brief white head.  Taste malts,spices,floral.  Clean finish, faint floral hops, palate thin, [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, minimal alcohol.

Overall I liked it, very decent German beer.

Clear light copper color, nice white head.  Aroma was distinctly malty, a touch of wert and a bit of breadiness.  Flavor matched, again malt focused, with the faintest touch of floral hops.  Good balancing bitterness. Well made beer.  Thanks to the wife for randomly picking this one up for me!

From the bottle, pours a clear light amber with a decent white bubbly head.  Aroma is malty, roasted, earthy.  Taste is earthy roasted malty, notes of caramel, a hint of floral hops.  Smooth and quaffable, good beer.

500ml bottle.  Deep orange pour with big white head.  Aroma of bread dough and floral hops.  Caramel and spice, some crackers.   Flavor of caramel and black pepper, some crackery dusty malt.  Light apple.  Nice floral and grassy hops.  Lively carbonation and medium bodied, very easy to drink.  Pretty nice, probably the best example of the style.

500ml brown bottle. Pours deep gold in colour with a well formed rocky white head. Minimal lacing. Malty nose with some caramel sweetness and light hop notes. Flavour is bready malt, grains, some grass. Finishes with mild lingering bitterness leading into a grassy aftertaste. Medium body, medium to high carbonation level. Good drinkability, fairly clean tasting and sessionable as a good o-fest should be.

Thank you sir may I have another.  This is so good, the flavors I get are butterscotch, caramel and bread.  It has a  very malty, creamy taste that goes down so smooth.  I havent had many oktoberfest marzen, but of the few I have had this stands on top... fantatic.  I really like this one, and I am going to stock up!

500 ml bottle poured into a tulip glass. Brilliant amber color with foamy white head. Beautiful beer to look at in the glass.  Floral notes with some malt characteristics.  Butterscotch flavor initially, followed by a bit of peppery spice notes. Finishes with some dry bready malty overtones.
Medium bodied, good carbonation Nice example of the style. Pretty smooth and easy to drink, yet spicy and flavorful. This would pair nicely with a grilled sausage or braut on a fall day.

Clear dark golden/amber pour thin off white head .... bready and sweet malt aroma .... very smooth and balanced taste of bready malts and sweet caramel malts along with sweet spices ... with a dry/bitter floral hop and earthy finish ... not too bitter just right .... a great example of an oktoberfest highly drinkable brew

This Marzen pours a clear pumpkin-orange color. A foamy white head forms fast upon pouring, but dissipates quickly.

Malts were evident on the nose as was expected. But butterscotch, and maybe even pumpkin, were a pleasant olfactory surprise.

Ayinger Oktober Fest Marzen is a wonderfully crisp and sweet brew suitable for drinking by itself or with food. Before eating, I found it to be clean, light, and refreshing. It could be a wonderful alternative to watered-down light beers on a hot summer day.

It was great beer for the low price of $2.49 here in Texas!

You can read my full review on my blog:
http://1yob.com/post/1050445861/ayinger

Poured from bottle. Color is a dark, luminescent gold-orange-amber with a soft, long-lasting ecru head. Nose has toast, spice (coriander/clove/nutmeg), apple, and just a touch of citrus (blood orange?). Taste starts sweet, then dries out quickly with more apple and spice, medium roast, and a dry crisp finish. Palate is appropriate. Nice, nice, very nice.

500 ml bottle.  Pours deep golden with a lasting head and medium carbonation.  Nose is sweet, juicy malt.  Crisp, medium body.  Bready, sweet malt dominate the palate, with some perfume and floral hops in the background.  Medium finish is more balanced.  The beer is lighter on hops and color than the best American Octoberfests, but its clean, easy drinking and overall delicious.
Clear, almost amber, good head.  A slightly fruity aroma along with a very malty taste with a bit of sweetness in the finish.

Pint at Winking Lizard Crosswoods. Clear amber pour with a thin beige head. Malty aroma with hints of grain, caramel and fruit. Grainy malt flavor with lager yeast, caramel and a bit of fruitiness. Could use some balancing bitterness, but decent overall.

16.9 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is a dull, but shimmering gold with an inch of foamy white head on top.  Nose is squash, light spice, dominant (but not overbearing) malt, and a light sweet honey.  Taste is right on par ... the malt and squash jump the gun, then the honey and spice swagger in and last very pleasantly through the finish.  This is a fantastic beer, let alone the best Oktoberfest Ive ever tried, and I really wish I had a case of this stuff.  I rated Paulaner high, but in hindsight, I could not give it the same rating after having this.  This is my first beer from Ayinger and I hope the rest of their line-up is not disappointing.
Clear copper colored. Smells malty and floral, and the taste is very well balanced between malt and hops. Excellent oktoberfest

The can make beers alright. This is probably one of the best of the style. Deep golden, clear with a small lingering head. The aroma is malty sweet with a bit of earthy floral notes. The flavor is very refreshing, full bodies, gulpible (is that a word?). Very dry finish leaves you wanting more.
Bottle pours a sharp clear copper with foamy white head. Scent of malts and butter melting. Taste is malty and mildly hoppy. Very nice!

Bottle: love the cap art. Pours a light golden amber - light white head. Smells like a floral fruity bouquet. I get apple cider and cinnamon out of this one, very pleasantly surprised. Nice caramel malt backbone, very light floral hops. Nice!

Bottle at my local cheese shop which i discovered has small selection of european brew.  Pours a crips copper color with a soapy white head.  Didnt get a lot on the nose.  Its slighty sweet with some floral and citrus.  its dry and has a decent finish.  nice early friday afternoon beer.

(16.9oz bottle).  Pours amber with pillowy white head.  Clear and lots of carbonation.  Aroma of floral, hay, slightly skunky and some anise.  Taste is sour then sweetness emerges.  Little bits of citrus and banana.  Hops are quite mild. Medium bodied with oily and somewhat creamy texture.  Not overly carbonated (fizzy). Finish is slightly bitter and smooth.  Very easy drinking beer. Well made and well balanced.

500ml in an Ayinger glass.  Pours deep, clear amber with a thick white head.  Aroma of bread and grains with some light hops.  Flavor mainly of the grains of the malts but a nice hop undertone.  Average body and texture.  German beer.

Slightly sweet, with literally no trace of alcohol. Felt like a deeper beer but not too complexand ended very fresh. I over chilled it just slightly, because the true aromas and flavors really came out after sitting for about 10 minutes. Beautiful carbonation that hit through to the end. I enjoyed this beer, especially the awesome bottle cap.
Excellent!! Fantastic malty nose, light hop. Classic golden color, clear with proper head. Lightly bitter brew with a medium body. Very accurate style. One of my favorite german breweries.

Bottle pours amber color with off white head.  Aroma is malty, yeasty (somewhat), and a little floral.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor has that beautiful german malt flavor, the water is german, with the german hops and yeast.  This brew takes me back to Munich at the end of September for Octoberfest.  It really did.  Great stuff.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2010 In bottle; pours nice amber color. This is the best oktoberfest/amrzen beer I have tried. Very easy drinking; a little sweeter than other oktoberfest beers. Great choice. OCT 8th - UPDATE - on top; enjoyed this beer once again. It is even better on tap than bottle; highly recommend
This is THE best Oktober Fest-Märzen I have ever had. There is no other. Smooth and sweet. This is the one beer you cant get enough of. Whatever these brewers did, they did it right!

Pours hazy golden amber with a creamy two-finger off-white head, minimal retention and lacing. Heavy malt aromas with a hint of bananas and caramel. Caramel sweetness, toast and and mild citrus notes. Full bodied, medium carbonation, bread and biscuits in the finish. Very pleasant.
Bottle. Golden brown pour with some white head.  Slight sweet caramel and bready malts, some light floral and citrus like hop notes.
One of the better marzens Ive had. Pour is copper. Nose and taste of banana, caramels and lots of lightly toasted malts. Rated 7/3/02

Big malty aroma, hint of banana on the nose.  Nice golden amber, with a head that peters out after a couple of sips.  Medium bodied, a slight touch of alcohol, texture is sticky on the tongue, and the perfect carbonation adds a soft coating to the mouth.  Big on malt, slight bitterness, finish is clean on the dry end.  Very easy to drink, yet extremely enjoyable.
A solid offering from what some consider to be the best Munich-area brewery,  Copper-colored with very little head, lingering finish and fairly sweet.  Good hops, balances the malt very well.

Sweet aroma and a bit hazy in the glass. Golden/copper color. Not a typical marzen. Did not make a good first impression but grew on me after a few sips. Sweet flavor but very drinkable. [500 ml bottle, BevMo]

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2011 Had a nice color. Subtle aroma. Was smooth going down. Left a good taste in the mouth.  10/2/11 The maltyness is delicious with this beer.  I seem to like it a lot more than last time I drank this beer.  I love fall beers.  Oh yes, love them.

Finally bit the bullet and bought a bottle.  Great amber color with fluffy white/off-white head.  Moderate carbonation.  Aroma is sweet caramel malts and alittle light hops and a little skunk.  A very mellow malt sweetness with crisp hop/dry finish.  Extremely drinkable, but like the Celebrator, lacking that flavor impact that I was expecting.  Again, for being at the top of rankings for Marzen, I am somewhat dissappointed and surprised.  Starting to think that its not worth paying the import price when local breweries have better offerings in these styles, and could much more use my dime.

500ml botlle.  Poured a deep orangish copper color with a frothy white head.  Big toasted malt aroma along with sweet fruits.  The taste begins with caramel and a sweet toasted malt flavor, rises toward a little hop bitterness, finishes dry, slightly sweet and with a late earth note.  A mellow Oktoberfest.
Bottle.  Copper pour with thick white head.  Sweet, honey, bread, toast, spice and hay.  Lighter to medium body with sweetness and some bitterness.

What a cool bottle cap!  Light amber pour with little head to speak of.  Pleasant medium body.  Mostly malt nose, but hints of floral hops permeate.  Thick malts and some nice notes of maple and molasses.  This has to be one of my favorite Marzen lagers.

Pours is amber colored with a thick white head.  Aroma is coconut, banana, and pear.  The flavors are bread and citrus with a coconut finish.  This beer has a medium/heavy body with light carbonation and a creamy mouth feel.  This one could stand to be slightly more bitter, but all together very enjoyable.
Wow.  I didnt know marzens could be this good.  Very drinkable.  Not much head, but great taste.

Bottle at Winking Lizard. Pours a dark gold (almost copper) with a generous white head. The aroma is quite nice with heavy notes of honey and toffee accompanying the floral hops with a mildly sweet background from the malts. The taste is also pleasing, as it is develops a fruity taste to accompany aroma. Medium bodied and finishes dry. I really enjoyed this one.
Bottle. Pours golden orange with a decent head. Aroma caramel, bread, citrus,  leather. Taste light sweetness, medium sourness, lightly bitter finish.

500ml bottle from Central Market.  Beautiful clear, amber-honey pour with 1-inch of off white head.  Bready, biscuit, toffee nose.  Active carbonation and light/medium body.  Mouthfeel is thicker than expected. Taste is same biscuit, toffee and roast malt.  A great O-Fest that makes me want to knock more than one or two back.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2010 500ml bottle, fresh 2010 batch.  No gusher this time.  Pours clear amber with a bit of copper/red and a nice sized off white head, recedes pretty quickly to a tiny ring, just a few spots of lacing.  Moderate strength aroma of toasted malts, caramel, some fruit, apple, a bit of floral hops.  Flavor features some toasted, caramel malt sweetness that is well balanced with some earthy and a touch spicy hops.  Finishes relatively dry.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, oily and a bit sticky, medium carbonation.  

Original review Dec 28, 2009:
500ml bottle.  A gusher.  Pours amber with a two finger white head.  Nice aroma, floral hops, some malt sweetness.  Flavor is a little more subdued, light floral and citrus hops, some sweetness and bitterness playing together nicely on the finish..  Medium to high carbonation.  Refreshing and easy-drinking.  Oh, and one of the coolest bottle caps Ive ever seen.
Aroma 7, Appearance 3, Taste 7, Palate 3, Overall 14, Score 3.4

I had a stash of Oktoberfests from October that I never got around to sampling and rating.  Amoung them this Ayinger.  The pour is orange hued, with medium yellow tinged head.  The aroma is sweet floral hops.  The flavor is very true to the aroma, the malts are nice and round not to roasty.  Very nice O-Fest.

Pours clear copper with a decent cream head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma of malt and yeast with a bit of hops, caramel, and toffee.  Taste similar to smell, but with a greater degree of progression.  Begins malty and yeasty.  Transitions to a sweeter caramel enhanced malty flavor.  Finishes with a combination of sweet caramel and hops.  Light-medium body with average carbonation.  Overall, excellent beer.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2011 Refigerated 16.9 oz bottle.  Pours clear light amber with a little off-white head.  Lightly carbonated, some lacing, and medium body. Taste is malty sweetness that finishes a little hoppy.  This is great, the best Oktoberfest style beer I have had.

500ml bottle served in a shaker pint. Pours a clear gold with a little amber tint. About a finger of white head. Malty aroma with some noble hops. You get that good malt complexity that only seems to come from Germany. A bit of malt sweetness. Crisp and clean with a fair amount of noble hop bitterness in the finish. On the lighter side of medium bodied. Great rendition of the style.

Situation: PSU heading toward a 3-0 start--time to prematurely celebrate...
Glassware: Schneider Edel Weisse....
Appearance: clear, dark copper body with subtle, steady effervescence; white head flattens quickly, which is surprising...
Aroma: fragrant malts mean business--but the balance of hops forms a welcoming pro-drinking atmosphere with toffee and caramel...
Palate: medium-bodied, throaty lager that engages the mouth completely; pleasantly substantial...
Taste: sweet but reserved, malty but with enough bite to have a hops reminder; a bit more complex than other fests Ive had...
Overall: a classic revisited--sweet, pleasant pairing with the Saturday afternoon...satisfyingly balanced...

bottle.  hazy orange pour with a sturdy off-white head and sudsy stick.  aroma is light hints of sweet malts and cookies.  slightly slick medium bodied.  sweet bready taste with caramel, apricot, light pumpkin spices and mild hops.  dry finish.  a little sweet for my tastes, but a really well constructed brew.
One of the best oktoberfest beers.  The malty nose and citrus hops make for a great relaxing birra!

Pours a dark golden yellow. Crystal clear with a thin, snow white head. Light, fruity aroma. Bread and sweet malt. Flavors of honey and sweet malt. Horehound ending that a rare handful of excellent marzens possess. Lighter on the palate but fuller then most marzen styles. Prickly carbonation. Probably the best marzen Ive ever had.
500 ml bottle given to me by a friend.  Pours a beautifule orange/amber color with an off-white head.  Flavor:  Sweet malt, with hints of honey, orange, and a dry finish

Bottle. Pours with a clear, light orange body and a large, creamy off-white head. Aroma of wet cereal, sweet, caramel malty, bread, clover honey and buttered toast. Taste is sweet and toasty with bread and caramel notes. Really taste actually. Medium to lively carbonation. Medium to light bodied. Crisp finish. Quite nice!

bottle. pours golden apple juice color. minimal head. aroma like cider, sweet honey, some funk.flavor is a bit understated from what I expected, but nice. malty sweetness that is a bit mild, followed by dry hoppy finish.  delicate for the style
UPDATED: DEC 18, 2009 Aroma is toasty and rather bready.  Pours out a burn orange with almost no head.  A grainy flavor that continues the bread aroma.  Body is light with a smooth light finish

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2010 More accustomed to Oktoberfests this year. Bottle from Chevy Chase Wine & Liqours.

Pours a nice clear orange.  Aroma is malty. Taste has light hops, heavy malt.

Definitely a favorite of Oktoberfests.

Poured a apricot color, with 3 finger with head, that is pretty frothy but looks to light to hang around too long. Aroma =has a bit of an earthy smell, can detect a little spice in it, but aroma is pretty weak overall. Taste = Wonderful malty backbone, getting a sweet, light peachy flavor in this, and a toasted bready flavor also.
This is a really exceptionally smooth, clean beer, feels light on the tounge.

Overall, this is an exceptionally good oktoberfest, possibly even my favorite so far.

Poured from half-liter bottle.  Sweet malt aroma.  Clear, golden.  Bubbly with thin head.  Flavor is roasted malt and sweet malt.  Dryer than most oktoberfest beers Ive tried.   Mellow, floral hops in back.  Crisp and clean.  Nice stuff.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Bottle courtesy of Sam at Hangar 24. Rating #729. Nice dark gold pour with a white head. Had a light toasted aroma, lots of graininess and slightly sweet, pretty good octo overall. (1039)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
UPDATED: SEP 6, 2011 Poured from bottle into Frankfurter glass.

Light orange-copper with moderate white head that disappears leaving no lacing.

Aroma of sweet fruit, caramel, biscuit and metallic bitterness.

Semi-sweet toasted malt with caramel, biscuit and fruit in the background. Ends on a spicy bitter note, more so than most Marzens.

Moderate carbonation, medium body, only semi-dry.

A solid Marzen overall. A little sweeter than Paulaner and not quite as good. While a decent brew, I honestly expected more.
Weak corn aroma. Clear amber, thin white head. Cheap malt flavor with a marigold finish. A poor showing for an authentic German Octoberfest.

Bottle. Hazy amber body with a large, frothy, off-white head, mostly lasting. The aroma is mostly malty with strong notes of sweet caramel and lighter notes of toasted bread, flowers and peach. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately bitter and lightly acidic. Medium body with a creamy texture and lively carbonation. The taste starts malty sweet, crisp, clean and turns nicely bitter. Nice balance. Excellent Oktobefest.
Clear golden, off white foam.  Grainy aroma, caramel, clean but lightly harsh bitterness.  Taste is more sweet, caramel, grainy.
Pours a clear straw yellow color with a soapy white head.  Sweet aroma with floral notes and some pils.  Flavor is sweet-floral with a slight bitter ending.  Smooth, creany refreshing.  Nice beer!

Not much of a nose.   Wonderful sweetness initially, lightly hopped, and an interesting finish - a bit of malt, with a bready/earthy tinge.  
Very solid, but unexceptional.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 500ml bottle into a big mug. There appears to be no freshness date on the label. 

Appearance: It has a rich deep golden color with very good clarity and some nice carbonation flowing up to the head. The head has a creamy off white color and rises up tall in the glass before slowly settling down to a nice foamy cap.

Smell: In the nose there are some sweet bready and light toasted notes with light grain and some floral/spicy hops.

Taste/Palate: The flavor has a very enjoyable malty character. There is mild sweetness, bready and light toasted grain notes, pie crust and very light caramel notes. This is balanced by some mild bitterness and notes of spicy/floral hops. The hops turn more leafy and mineral like in the finish which is crisp and refreshing. Its body has a solid medium to full feel with well balanced carbonation.

Notes: This is a very well made Oktoberfest. To me its like a Munich Helles Lager but a little deeper in color, richer and fuller in flavor and body with the same wonderful drinkability.

sweet nose that is not too strong. light brown pour with a nice foamy off white head. Taste of caramel and i agree with the taste of sweet hay or straw. lingers nicely on the palate. very smooth mouth feel.
Draught at Mallaskukko Turku. Pale head. Pale coppery colour. Mild nose. Slightly sweet malty taste. Average hoppiness.

500 ml bottle purchased at Lukas in Overland Park, Kansas. Pour is hazed copper orange with a big three inch tan white head. Head falls slowly with nice lacing. Soft carbonation floats to the surface. Pretty. Aroma of sweet straw and hay malt, with floral notes and a bit of a dirty mechanical odor. The mechanical odor detracted quite a bit. Taste has less of the dirty oily element of the nose, but is still present along with sweetish honey and straw malt and the soft floral. Palate is medium, low carb but still easy drinking. There was a nice beer in here, though it was outweighed by the dirtiness. I will give it another try someday.
bottle.  Pours a clear amber with a huge, off-white head.  Nose is lagery and spice with nuts and dirty socks.  Taste is is nut, bread and spice.  Mouthfeel is smooth and carbonated.  Not bad.

500ml bottle. Pours a hazed golden-yellow body with a finger-width, white, fizzy head that dissipates quickly and leaves a good amount of lacing. Aroma is malty sweet with notes of apricot and lemon. A mild toffee-cookie with some biscuit, yeast, and a very light grassy hop. Flavor is also malty with a moderate sweetness. Fresh bread and yeast, a light grassy hop, and lots of floral fruits. That toffee-cookie comes back and yields a hint of toast and honey towards the finish. A soft dryness as advertised after a very smooth, medium body. Lots of pleasant malts in the aftertaste along with some fruits, straw hops, and a light toasty cookie. Overall, a very tasty, well balanced, all-around good beer. Solid.

On tap at Club Tavern in Menasha, WI. Pour was medium clear golden with a white head. Aroma was of sweet malt, light hops, and light caramel. Flavor was very floral with a strong biscuit malt flavor. Very well blended and smooth. Good brew.
From a bottle poured a light amber color with a fair amount of head.  Nice light malty flavor with a quick finish.

Bottle. Pours a clean, clear brownish orange color with a small white head that receeds to a ring. Nose is a very nice, clean caramel sweet malt with a light honey note to it. Fresh bicuits. Palate is crisp with a fizzy note in the finish. Flavor is a nice toasty biscuit with a light caramel sweetness. Finishes lightly filmy with a nice crispness.

Really the standard by which I compare Ofests.  Deep, deep gold color with orange highlights and a white head.  Noble hop aroma with plenty of malt and just a slight sulfury note.  Flavor is intense malt but with a clean finish and noble hop character.  Beautiful balance of rich maltiness without being cloying and without the caramel flavors that so many US brewers insist on putting in their beers.  What a great beer.

i love this stuff. easily one of the best, if not the best oktoberfest out there. has that malty, sweet almost official oktoberfest smell and tastes so simple but so perfect. tastes like an alcoholic werthers original candy sucker thingy. love it!!
Golden orange with a large frothy off-white head.  It has a sweet, lightly hopped aroma.  The medium body is lively and finishes semi-dry and lightly acidic.

Pours hazy amber color with off white head. Sweet fruit, caramel and bread aromas. Flavor is moderately sweet caramel and some fruits. Medium body with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. An excellent Oktoberfest brew.
1 pt 9 oz bottle.  Nice amber pour with a thick light tan head.  Aroma of caramel malt.  Fantastic taste of malt and sugar with that familiar Oktoberfest sharp finish.
Draft. Pours golden amber with a creamy, off-white head. Hoppy aroma, with hints of yeast, malt, spice, and wheat. Medium body with a weak finish. Sub-par Oktoberfest.

Exactly what I want an Oktoberfest beer to taste like. Pours a rich brown-gold with a lingering head. Malty aroma with slight hints of grain. Flavor is nice malt with a little hop, which balances out well. Smooth with a nice finish, sweet yet mildly bitter. Great stuff.

Bottle. Pours a clear deep golden body with an orange tint. Medium sized with head with some decent lacing. Really hard for me to pick this aroma out but I got a lot of cereal and malt with the smallest amount of yeast, fruit and hops. Crisp, smooth, mellow, full bodied mouthfeel. Nice balance of sweet malts with a slightly bitter finish. Very easy drinking beer. Really enjoyable.

Tap at some North Seattle bar and grill.

Pretty amber pour, pretty off-white head. Soft malty aroma with hints of fruit; lovely flavor of whole wheat just out of the oven, light orchard fruits, a decent hop touch in the close. Full-bodied rather than ultra-sesionable yet easier to quaff than 95% of the local stuff. Pretty darn classic.

Bottle. Pours an attractive light copper with a frothy white head. Nose of rich caramel toastiness and noble hops. Notes of toffee, bread, toasty rich maltiness followed by balancing herbal, earthy hop character. The takeaway is pleasant, non-cloying malty sweetness. Very satisfying. Body is medium full, with soft carbonation. Great o-fest.
500 ml. - Pours lightly cloudy amber, with a malty flavor. It also has a bitterness that follows. Way better than Paulaner Oktoberfest.

Bottle.  Pours a crisp, clear caramel color with medium white head.  Aroma is caramel, fresh toasted bread with a slight floral undertone.  Flavor is very smooth, bready notes and toasted malt to start then caramel and a slight touch of hops and a wheat bitterness.  Very smooth on the palate, extremely quaffable.  Fantastic beer, tops in the style.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2012 500 ml bottle--8 oz sample.  Strong, strong grain presence in the nose; also banana esters.  Hazy golden appearance.  Tastes of roasted grain.  More importantly, it tastes like autumn.  Pobably the best Oktoberfest Ive tried, although Im still not too crazy about the style.

Ayinger, youre good!  First, Celebrator is clearly the best doppelbock.  Now Ive tasted your Marzen, and its clearly the best Ive ever had as well.

Large bottle, just over a pint.  Pours a clear orangey gold with a medium-sized fluffy white head.  Decent lacing as well.

Smells of caramel sweetness and yeast, with a nice crisp white grape twist.  The flavor is simple and great, with more of that caramel malt sweetness and the earthy goodness of the yeast and a bit of spice.  White wine dryness and a slightly bitter finish.

Moderately carbonated to help cut through the creamy moderate thickness of the brew.  Very little alcohol apparent, perfect for an all-day session in Munich.

Pours a clear, orange-gold amber with a decent white head. Aroma is fairly strong and malty with yeasty and fruity hints. Mouth-filling malty flavor has a slight fruity undertone and just a touch of caramel. Texture is nicely smooth and fairly tingly. Prosit!

As good a Märzen as Ive ever tried.  Im trying this against Spatens version, and the Ayinger is the clear winner.  The beer pours a relatively light amber-golden color with a smallish white head and pretty good retention.  The beer smells of peaches, apples and concord grapes.  Its very pleasant, even if that description makes it sound oversweet.  Its a light but rich malty character that transmits to the flavor quite well.  The beer is has a delicate and complex malt character that has fruit and caramel notes.  The Germans really know how to tease out delicate malt flavors.  The finish is mildly bitter and cuts out much of the lingering sweetness.  Its a very drinkable beer, and Id be quite happy spending a day drinking this beer out of enormous steins.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2011 (bottle 9/27/10). Copper color with light cloudiness. Large off white head. Light toast/malt aroma. Moderate caramel flavor, with light toast. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Thin texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.
--
Initial rating: 2.8 on 10/3/09. (bottle). Clear amber color. medium off white head. Light malt and hay aromas. Light sweet roasted malt flavor. Avg duration. Slightly astringent finish. Thin/slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

Bottle. Pours amber with a large fluffy off-white head, nice lacing. Nice caramel, soft toasted malts, some fruit and a touch of spicy hops. Toasty sweet malts, slight fruits, a touch of alcohol at it very warmest, earthy hop finish. Very smooth, lush mouthfeel. Very drinkable.
The best ocktoberfest out there. Rich amber color with thin white head. Aromas of sweet caramel and roasted citrus. Creamy mouthfeel and smooth finish.

wow, i saw that the rating was really high for this, but i still didnt think it would be this good. usually the highest ratings are for beers that are hard to get. one of the best marzens ive ever had, so well balanced and a great finish.

A clear amber pour, this Oktoberfest/Marzen is a nice beer that is fruity on the nose with flavors of yeast and malt and a nice hop crispness in the finish.  There is a slight sweetness that lingers throughout, and I love that classic German flavor!   I have to get to Germany and Belgium.

17oz bottle via HAgen. Pours a near clear orange with a large beige head. Nose is toasty. Taste is buttered toast, biscuits, toffee, chocolate malt, almonds, and some fruity esters. This is about the toastiest beer i have had is some time, And is very tasty and easy to drink. Body is medium, carbonation light/medium Awesome beer and best Octoberfest beer i have had to date!
Golden amber in color. Lightish thin white head. Nose of yeast and freshness. Really fresh for an Octoberfest. Crisp flavor with just enough creamy maltiness. Best festbier that Ive this season.
This Oktoberfest has a strong body and a hearty mouthfeel. A smooth spicy bread flavor with a strong malt base.
nice copper color with a white head.  scents of fruit and malty sweetness.  a great aftertaste of lingering fruit with a balance of malt.  one of the best oktoberfest beers in th world.
Straw color, thick white head.  Faint aroma, slight floral notes with some honey.  Honey flavor with a sweet buttery finish that coats your palate (in a good way).  Very nice lacing as well.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2009 Chicken Charlies, Washington, PA - This is my favorite Octoberfest.  Pours a light amber color with a moderate amount of white head.  Excellent blend of spices and a nice sweet flavor countered with malt, without a doubt the best tasting Marzen that I have had.  Body is pretty light, but to be expected from this style.

Pours a clear light golden orange color with a thin .5 finger off-white fizzy that that quickly dissipates into a thin ring that leaves minimal lacing.

Sweet malt aroma with subtle floral hops and yeast , brown sugar, biscuit and cinnamon. Kind of bland actually.

Medium bodied and kind of watered down with a decent balance of sweet malt, subtle spice, bready yeast and floral hops. The malt profile is slightly toasty with some sweet caramel notes. Slightly dry finish. Well-balanced but not something that I would seek out regularly.

Transparent amber pour with a medium sized white head. Aroma is a bit of yeast and wheat, toasty malt, caramel, and a hint of citrus and grass hops. Flavor is similar, with the doughy yeast coming out a bit more. Really excellent for a lager, a top notch marzen for sure. Good stuff.

Clear amber pour with a half finger white head that slowly dissipates. Aroma is toasty malt, hints of caramel, citrus, and some sweet malt notes. Flavor is mostly sweet toasty malt with some yeasty dough in there as well. Not too much going on, but what it does it does well. Palate is exceptionally smooth and pillowy, finishing sweet and clean. A great brew for the style.
UPDATED: SEP 21, 2009 A clear orange color with a small white head.  Aroma is toasty and a little grassy .  Flavor is of toasty grain, a bit of appley fruitiness.  A remarkably good lager.

I generally dont prefers lagers, but this is a fantastic example of marzen. A very light, clear amber color with a small head. Aroma is subtle but with sweet, caramel nose. Light taste that is one of that smoothest beers Ive ever had.

Poured from the bottle a clear, orange color with a dense bubbly white head. A strong apple juice note, light floral hops, sweet caramel, light hay grain with some light toasted malt notes but mostly sweet apple presence. Flavor has a sweet apple and grape fruitiness up front, a straw/hay grainy middle, a very mild grass and noble hops note with a very sweet caramel malt ending. Great syrup/sugary density to it, mild carbonation rate and a semi-creamy note. Overall a great Oktoberfest brew and one I will definitely look forward to when the fall season comes a knocking.
Good beer, but not the best Oktoberfest ever, Weak, but very good flavor.  I wish it was a stronger flavor.

500ml bottle. Pours apple cider with small, quickly dissapoearing white head. Smells bready, sweet and malty. Tastes mostly like apple juice, bread, and grassy. Carbonation is noticable, but goes down smooth. No alcohol noticeable. 1st Marzen Ive had, but this is German tasty.

pours light amber with a thick foamy off white head.
Aroma is light grassy hop over a nice bready and cookie toned malt, sweet and toasty.
Flavour is nice and smooth. Medium bodied sweetness, bready again with light spice cookie hints. somewhat dry finish.

Fresh bottle from Sams. Pours more deep gold than orange, with an abundant head and some decent lacing.  Toasty malts and mild hops on the nose.  Some bread and mild citrus as well as apricot.  Slight gravel taste, but in a good way. Actually, this is quite bready/toasty with a rich sweet finish and full body. Best marzen out there, perhaps... thats what the ratings say, and I dont think I can disagree.

Brewed in Germany... Pours a golden amber color with a super thin white head and lots of carbonation. Aroma of bread, malts, flowers and caramel. Taste of bread, honey, caramel and flowers. Mouthfeel in medium in body with a slight dry sweet finish. This beer is very pleasant to drink and would be wonderful at your local O-Fest. :)

A one inch foamy tan head.  This beers has a nice appearance, aroma and good carbonation.  A medium mouth feel, with roasted malts and hints of caramel. Some Pumpkin and cinnamon thrown in there as well. A true Oktoberfest with that authentic German taste that is so often attempted to be replicated.

Serving: 500 ml bottle.
Appearance: Pale amber with a very effervescent, foamy, white head.  Okay head retention.
Aroma: Light toast and cracker notes.  Dead on for the style I believe.
Taste: Malty and smooth with a bit of metallic and caramel notes.  A bit on the sweet side.
Palate: Medium, smooth carbonation.  Very soft on the tongue.  Medium, slightly dry mouthfeel with a medium-short, sweet finish.
Overall: This one starts off great but is just a bit too sweet.  Still, it is very good for the style.  Worth giving a try if you are into Marzens.
now this is what an  oktoberfest should taste like! it has the right amount of everything. by far my top choice

Pours dark golden color with a small off whitish head. Sweet aroma, a mix of malt and floral hops. The flavor is good, mostly malty (bread), a little nuttiness and some mild hops. The flavor lasts in the enjoyable aftertaste, medium body, would love to get a liter of this on tap in Germany.

Clear light amber with an off-white head.  Scent of honey and malt in a refreshing combination, later turning to floral hop aromas with malt.  Light yet robust flavor with unassuming mouthfeel.  Very good Oktoberfest - the only beer of the style thats impressed me yet.

Pours clean and a goldeny orange. Aroma is a fruity boquet that is not over powering. Tastes is bright with malts, some dried fruits and mild hops. The palet stays with you without overpowering but leaving wanting another sip. A nice beer to start a the fall season or a good evening by an outside fire.

Bottle pours a clear, golden, orange color with a dense, foamy, white head.  Sweet, bready malt, honey, caramel, and apple aromas.  Flavor has more of the bready malt characteristics along with dried fruit and hoppy notes.  Nice lingering aftertaste.  Tasty.

My friend, Hugo, at Specs gave me the heads up on this brew....wow, was he right. I like just about everything in this beer. A sweet aroma, with some citrus and honey hints thrown in. Looks very fresh in the glass, great dark orange color, with medium clarity, and plenty of carbonation. A full body, with great, soft malt tones and sweet flavors. Not much prominent hops here. Washes down smoothly.  A great way to finish the day.....and begin the evening...

Picked up a fresh bottle at Johns Grocery, awesome!
Pours a bright orange with a big fluffy head. The aroma has some faint apricot, some anise and some nuttiness, a complex bouquet that keeps your nose in the glass. The flavor is very malty with some horehound, some saltiness, and plenty of noble hop bitterness, much like the aroma the flavor of this is wonderfully complex.
Poured an amber color wwith a white head. Aroma was grassy, sweet malts. Flavor was malty grassy and some spice herbal notes too.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2011 On tap at Flying Saucer Houston. Pours a clear golden orange with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has some sweet grains and bread with a bit of caramel and raisin. Flavor starts with sweet grains and is joined a bit by caramel and raisin. Easy drinking.

Pours a burnt tangerine with a nice fluffy white head. The aroma is bready malt, cereal, and a faint hint of some grassy hops. Has a sweet flavor of rich malt and a near crisp finish. Medium bodied with light but zesty carbonation. Very good Marzen.

500 ml. bottle. Pours a thin white head, over a slightly cloudy Pale amber (SRM 8-9) body.....nose is very malty, with cereal, carmel, some spice notes....tastes primarily of sweet malts, with soft caramel, toffee, cereal, somewhat sweet throughout....mouth feel is light and soft, carbonation low. Meets the style exactly.
Light color for the style with a nice retaining head. Aroma and taste of malt and crackers, less sweet and caramelly than others. Hints of roasted malts.
A favorite oktoberfest beer of mine with strong malt flavors. Crisp and refreshing to drink.
I liked the light amber colour of this one, likewise the good-sized white head.  Aroma was of both malt and hops.  The taste was again malt and hops, nicely balanced, crisp, clean, and refreshing.
Bottle.  Pours an orange copper body with a white head.  Caramel malt hints of honey and earth y floral notes.  Lighter citrus dried fruit with bread y notes. Nice.

A brilliant orange with faintly darker hues of brown and amber. She is crowned by a soft, creamsicle head which lingers long into her final moments while commemorating our time together with small patches of lace. My first whiff of her nose bursts and crackles with fresh butterscotch candies, white bread crackers, candied fruit, crunchy apples, pears, and oranges. Delicate and subtle, her aromas are woven together in an intricate network of finesse and skill. In the background, toasted malts are drizzled with fresh honey. Her nose is balanced exquisitely, but how will her palate hold up? Clean, and only of medium-weight, she lightly coats my mouth in a soft butterscotch glaze while toasted bread settles into the background. Cinnamon sticks and powdered cinnamon add a dry breath of spice to balance the malty sweetness. As I bite into her crisp peaches and pears, their juices trickle down my throat while their skins add a brisk acidic nip for a playful measure. In the background, further soothing notes of butterscotch and maple linger into her finish while her fruits sit squarely in the middle. Deliciously dry, brisk, and bright, as I enjoy the last of my Ayinger Oktoberfest, I feel an honored witness to living history.


Ayinger never fails to impress me with their constant consistency and quality of beers. They may not win any awards for originality, but what they do best is bring their beers of ancestry to life, honoring long-standing traditions and tastes. Never think about whether or not to bring home an Ayinger beer, just do it.

Bottle. Pours a toffee gold with an off-white head, not thick but laces well. Nose is hops and caramel, with nice lagery-fruitiness. Soft, toffeeish/caramel mouthfeel with plenty of fruit. Good stuff.

Bottle. Clear deep amber/gold with a small off white head. Aroma of bread, caramel, and spicy yeast. Dominatly sweet malt base with a sour and bitter flavor in the background. Very smooth soft mouth feel, medium body and average carbonation. This is an excellent Marzen and very drinkable.

Pours clear amber, with a one-finger beige head, very fine, lasting lacing.    Smells of carmael, apple, banana, grass, and a little earthy.  Light-body, creamy, crisp and lightly dry.  Tastes of caramel, biscuit, apple, spice, and citrus.  Very well balanced and drinkable.

500 ml bottle. It has probably been sitting for about a year. pours a light copper with a small/average white head. aAoma has hints of apples ,some fruit and spices. Favor is about the same with mild bitterness. Very sweet. I.m not the biggest lager.marzen fan,but this one was good.

500ml Bottle  Leavenworth, WA
Aroma: Nice malt aroma with some spices and light fruit aromas lingering.  
Appearance: Amber in color, Hazy with a thin head.  
Flavor: Very malty beer with a nice smattering of spices added to the brew.  Very crisp. 
Palate: Dry Wheat Finish, with a Good Mouthfeel.  
Overall: Had to have another German Beer here in Leavenworth WA it was over 99 degrees and I needed a cold beer.

White grape, plum, apples and caramel round out the aroma. Appearance is light red with a little lacing in the glass. Flavor has some ripe apple, bread, caramel and sour grape. Palate is fizzy. Good, but not too outstanding.
The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass also. Starts spicy, fresh, reminds me of gouda-cheese for a short moment. Yeasty-spicy finish, not too dry. Well done!

Bottle from jessup plaza. thanks chuck. Poured a nice amber color with a big off white head that lasted a long time. Aroma is sweet malt and some caramel. Taste is nice and big. Lots of malt sweetness and mild hops at the end. Pretty good marzen.
Sweet and malty beginning, light, somewhat watery, sticky fruity and flowery hops. Fair Oktoberfest.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of roasted, and bisquit, light herbs for the hops, light yeast notes of leather and earth, with backround notes of butter, honey, and faint spice. Head is large, frothy, slightly off-white, with fair lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is clear orange/tan. Flavor starts lightly sweet and acidic then finishes lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, watery with a lively carbonation and finishes lightly metallic. This was a tough beer not to down in a few gulps. Great tasting and easy drinking.

Bottle as shown. Pours a copper golden with a large frothy white head taht lasts awhile. The aroma is a wheat malt with grain and caramel. Good sticky lacing on the glass. Thin mouthfeel with a sour taste and a sweet finish. Easy to drink, a decent marzen from Ayinger.

500 ml bottle, but says 5.6% abv.  Pours a gold color with a small, clingy, beige head that slowly fades.  Taste is of caramel, malt and some hops.  Similar aroma  Has a good bitterness to it and is a little sweet.  Has a foamy mouthfeel.  Easy to drink and fairly enjoyable.  Not as great as what I thought it would be.  Neat looking bottle and cap.

Enjoyed via 16.9oz bottle.  Pours a medium to deep gold.  Nose of Munich malt, and a touch of fresh-baked German dark bread.  Smooth and balanced on the palate; malt up front with just a touch of balancing hops.  Initial hop bitterness and flavor may be a little higher, as this example is nearly one year old.  Finishes clean, just a touch flowery, and just barely on the sweet side of neutral.  The quintessential German Oktoberfest beer.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2009 This guy is beautiful, with a huge long-lasting head. Unfortunately, it tastes like bread. If I wanted that, I would just eat bread. I prefer a strong, sweet malty character, this was dry and doughy. Only worth it for the bad-ass looking cap.
Updated rating= Wow, I have really come to want the crisp, clean tasting mouthfull of bread. Unfortunately, it makes me more thirsty. But I guess thats the point.

From the Bottle Aroma is sweet and deep very yeasty. Looks very nice. Flavor is very malty. Mouth feel is very dry and under pronounced. An interesting brew. It is cold as shit in southern Alberta right now and I think this beer would better suit the summer.

500 ml, 5.6% abv. Clear, burnt orange-amber with a quarter inch of frosting above. Aromas of grilled corn, sweet cherry, apple, cereal grain and hay. Flavor is caramel with a sour tint, hearty toasted grain and light apple. Finish is crisp and grassy-woody. Medium body is smooth, tongue-tingly and slightly astringent. Creamy lace left on the glass.
Amber with creamy head.  Chocolate, spice, and malt.  Refreshing and well constructed,  but nothing special

Light amber pour.  Whitish head. Aroma of malt, malt and more lamt.  Some caramel and bready notes evident as well. Flavor is full of a nice full bodied malt, bread and some caramel.  All in all tihs is good shit.

Sadly, this style is a rarity (locally-brewed or imported) in this part of the world. It was nice to sample Ayinger, which poured with a creamy head over a copper-coloured body. The aroma was of lightly-toasted malt, with a slightly sweet, syrupy accent. The flavour was bready, though the toasted malt made it more like bread crusts. Nice dry finish, but the body could have been a bit smoother: the carbonation was a little prickly for the style.

Poured amber in color with a creamy, off-white head that settle to a thin cover and left light lacing. The aroma was of caramel, spices, and a light roast. The flavor found chocolate and spices. Light body with a malty aftertaste.

Pours a golden amber with a nice sized head that dissapates but never really goes away. Aroma is malty, floral, some buttery toast, caramel, and a hint of crusty leaves. Tastes very buttery, tuns of toffee, toasted malt, spice and nuttyness. Really nice mouth feel, creamy and pleasantly sticky. Has a nice finish that lingers pleasantly. Really nice beer.

Pours an orange amber color with a huge white head that falls off to some nice sticky white lace around the glass. Aroma is bready maltiness, caramel and some spiciness from the hops. Flavor is bready caramel maltiness with some spiciness from the hops in the finish.

A- Pours a clear dark orange hue with amber tones, huge craggy off-white head that settles down to a thin layer, moderate lacing
S- Nose is moderate bread/biscuit malts and yeast, hints of caramel, spices, and slight citrus hops, very refreshing
T- Initial taste is sweet and rich malts with an overall bready flavor, transitions to grain and nuts (pecans), finishes with slight hop bitterness that resolves quite quickly
M- Light-to-medium body, creamy texture with lively carbonation
D- Nicely balanced marzen that seems to capture the essence of the traditional octoberfest style, very easy-to-drink with a robust taste profile
Tried on tap at Ginger man.  I didnt have very strong feelings either way on this one.

500ml bottle.  Pours an orange-gold color with a thick, white head.  Sweet malty, yeasty aroma.  Delicious combination of malts and citrus on the palate with a slightly bitter hop aftertaste.  A refreshing brew that is a steal for the price.
Copper in color with a good sized off-white head. Aroma is of fruits, sweet malts, caramel and lightyeast and bread dough. Taste is caramel, yeast, biscuit, a little nuttiness, and sweet malt.

500 ml bottle.  Pours very orangey copper colour.  Decnt head, slightly off white in colour, leaves nice lacing.  Aroma not particularly strong, flavour is malty, sweet, hint on honey.  Colour is a bit off putting, very orange.  Quite drinkable.

2008 Bottle.  A very good marzen, but not the best.  Wonderful aroma, full and malty.  Nice amber appearance with little head.  Tastes of well-roasted malts and a quickly dissipating hoppy aftertaste.  Appropriately oily palate, so as to leave you satisfied without a weird aftertaste lingering.  Well done, as always, Ayinger.
sweet and malty, lots of nice  caramel, littkle bit of honey, not much on the hop front. still very good.

Poured an attractive copper color with nice white head that lasted a while. Aroma was of sweet malt, caramel, and just a bit of hop aroma. Flavor is pretty much the same with the sweetness being offset by just a bit of hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is good. Beer is good, but Ive had much better O-fests.

Bottle, Christmas gift.  Poured an orange, light amber color with a medium to large, long lasting off white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, bread, fruit, yeast and vanilla.  One of the best tasting of the style that I have had.  Alot of sweentess, caramel and bread in the forefront, with a touch of earthy bitterness in the finish.  A long and pleasing aftertaste.  Nice session beer.
UPDATED: OCT 5, 2009 Pours an off-white head with some lace and a clear, pale amber body.  Aromas of grassy hops and toffee.  Flavor is butter, caramel, corn, malt.  Dry finish.
Pours a light amber with quite a bit of head. Strong caramel malt flavor that finishes slightly bitter. Pretty decent Octoberfest brew.

Bottle. A clear orange/amber color pour with a large fluffy off white head. Nice lacing and lively carbonation. Aroma is of sweet toasted nutty caramel malt,apple,and a hint of spice very pleasent. The flavor blew me away,a huge sweet malty nutty taste,with some hints of bread,peaches and maybe some orange zest. A good creamy mouthfeel. Just a hint of bitter hops at the end.  VERY GOOD !

Bottle--Excellent, excellent brew.  Not too deep of an amber color, almost orange with a large, froathy head.  Once the pour is finished, the malty aroma hits you, it is strong.  The taste is almost all malts itself, this is the way I like an Oktoberfest.  The hop finish starts to appear as the beer begins to warm.  As the drink finishes, it begins to balance out the hops with the malts.  Great job, great beer.  Produce place.

Clear amber-orange pour with a big dense tan head that leaves generous lace.  Aroma strongly yeasty and malty with a twist of green apples.  Flavor is very yeasty and bready, with a little citrus, gumball, and clove.  A slight metallic tang was sometimes detectable, but this was the only off element.  Medium bodied,  well carbonated, crisp mouthfeel.

Surprisingly average given the hype.  Maybe I am just not a huge fan of this style or of Brauerei Aying. Similar to Sam Adams Octoberfest. Good, but not special. Strong caramel malt, hardly any hop character, slightly bitter finish.  Standard Oktoberfest appearance and mouthfeel.

Pours clear orange amber with good white head.  Sweet vanilla aromas with caramel.  Sweet, buttery, malty classic marzen flavor.  Medium body with moderate carbonation.  Excellent example of a german ofest, but im not the biggest fan of this style.

From a 0.5 L bottle purchased locally. Aroma is rich with malt with a little sweetness and maybe a hint of orange peel and something slightly mango peppery in there in a good way. Deep golden color with a big off-white head, crystal clear. Flavor is bready rich malt with some of that toasty malt from the aroma. Some sweetness but balanced with the slight hint of bitterness. Clean and drinkable. Makes me want some bratwurst.

Cute cap.  Rust / orange colored pour with a plush head and spotty lacing.  Aroma is mild and sweet, with noticeable yeast and Mitteleuropean hops.  The flavor is fresh, malty, and bready, but with a little corny sweetness.  Modestly hopped and light on the palate.  A good beer of its kind.
Pretty solid Octoberfest. Solid malt presence....crisp flavor and good finish. Overall a good octoberfest.

(10/13/08) Draught at Map Room in Chicago. Clear deep golden color with a small white head. Malty aroma with some toast and caramel notes as well as nutty hints. Sweetish malty flavor with caramel, toasted bread, some light fruitiness and light buttery hints.  Medium-bodied. Nothing exciting, but OK.
bottle picked up at kegs and barrels in mckinney tx.  poured a clear orange with a thin white head.  aroma of malt, spice, and caramel.  flavor of malt, spice and hops.  very well balance o-fest.
Found a bottle 11/1/08 in Wordens in Missoula, MT. It is very good. Sweet and malty, with a little bit of a Belgian taste.  Thumbs up! A nice Octoberfest brew.

Surprisingly, I found this diamond in the rough at a local farmers market. I was pleasantly surprised because I know that it is one of the highest rated Oktoberfest beers. I am looking at it right now. The head is nice. It doesn’t fade away fast. The color/appearance is a light caramel/orange/brown color. This beer is very transparent. Decent looking marzen, but I wish it could be a bit darker. VERY malty. This beer has a very sweet aroma. The beer is still pretty cold and the malt aroma is jumping out at me! This is a very pungent Oktoberfest beer. I can’t get over how malty the aroma is. Smells great! The beer has a nice dry hop flavor. The beer is balanced well with caramel malt flavor. Jeez, this beer has a wonderful hop profile for being as malty as it is. I am very impressed with this balance. I just can’t get over the dry hop flavor at the end. It is great. Not too many brewers are able to achieve this balance in a beer this malty. As the beer warms up, the hops and the malts come out even more. Overall, this is an excellent Oktoberfest beer. Probably one of the best that I have tried. I would definitely drink this more often if it were more accessible.
From bottle.  Part of September Dayton Beer Tasting event.  Pours deep golden.  Some floral hops with a trace of sweetness.  Slightly dry finish with decent complexity.  Good effort.

Ayinger Oktober Fest Märzen has a deep golden color tinted with amber. It is lightly sweet with a malty nose balanced with floral hops. Its medium to big body and alcohol is not overpowering. The soft dryness comes from long maturation.

Tap @ Mallaskukko.
Reddish orange color, light tan head. Not very strong aroma, but it has soft maltiness. Full malty taste accented by slight dryness and smooth bitterness towards the end. Excellent balance all the way. Very enjoyable, highly recommended.

Draught @ Kaunis Kampela, Helsinki. Burnished gold color, thick white head. Malty aroma with some wood. Smooth malty flavor with noticeable bitterness. Not a bad märzen at all, but somehow the flavor didn’t entice me completely.

wonderful aroma of the farm during harvest. so well balanced with slick caramel sweetness and (thanx austone) buttery taste and mouthfeel. malty and full of grains with slight fruitiness just barely present and  a perfect moderate alcohol content that is soft and not at all weak. just right for the season and one of my perfect pints.
Had a liter of this at gingermans in a über stein that I ganked. Light brown pour, mellow notes of caramel and earthy malts. A nice way to celebrate Oktoberfest.

Pours red-copper with a good sized light beige head that lasts a long time and  leaves decent lacing. Aroma is lots of caramel, toasty, sweet and grainy malts. Hops are present but merely provide a grassy, leafy backdrop to the spectacular malt nose. Flavor is basically a repeat of the nose, with the addition of some nice toffee, buttery and nutty malt notes takeing over quite a bit for the grassy hops. Finish is a pleasant continuation off the toffee, and grain malts, with some leafy and a tiny bit of bitter hops. Body is medium, a little sticky, and a little over carbonated. Overall pretty good, probably one of the best marzens or oktoberfests, including viennas, that I have had.
Absolutely the best Oktoberfest available in South Carolina. Can be hard to find, but it is out there.

Draught at Mallaskukko. Copper, firm white head. Toasty, sweet malty aroma, dried fruits and grassy hops. Caramel malty, toasty flavor, buttery nuttiness and herbal hops in the finish. A bit over carbonated palate. Nicely chewy märzen, just a hint more hops and it’s there.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2009 pours a golden clear with a orangish hue, with big off white head this the highest ranked marzen i could get my beer monger hands on in chicagoland area bottle 1.9 oz if my facts are correct this is one of the 5 breweries in germany that has been supplying beer for octoberfest since its beginnings. aromas are of malts and hops taste  is of slightly caramelized mallts and a very nice mild hopping, thin and smooth,the best of the germanns
Floral hoppy aroma, sweet malty, dry and bitter taste. Mouthfeel is soft. Most impressive example of the style so far for me, this is really good and now I get the idea of one liter pints...
This was a good oktoberfest.... on tap at winking lizard... amber poor with nice creamy head and good lacing.  carmel and malt notes with a crisp macantosh finish... Oktoberfest needs to last longer

on tap@gingerman in norwalk. Typical ofthis style, redish-amber body with a fast fading whte head.  Caramel malt aroma. Flavor was mostly sweet malt notes. A truly unique palate were the beer seemed thin, but seemed overall heavy on the stomach. Areally crisp finish.
Great orange/yellow color.  Nose sweet malt.  Flavors citrus/bitter hop character/light banana.

nice orange color, fluffy head, a bit of lacing.  aroma of wet musty malt, also sweet malt.  flavor has some roasted grain, honey sweetness, creaminess.  full bodied, oily mouth feel, dry finish.  a good oktoberfest, but i am beginning to get a bit oktoberfested out this season.

Foxy-orange beer, clear, with a small cream-beige coloured head. Bottom of bottle shows scary UFOs, but they stick to their place. Earthy-leafy nose, with some caramel apparent. Strange extra aroma, as from the frying fat from roast fowl. Leafy, earthy flavours and pretty bitterish from beautiful continental noble hops; fine and delicate and tasty at the same time. Finishing dry-bitter, and still leaving an impression of fruitiness behind. Another one with amazing balance. Warming up, this roast-fat creeps into the taste as well. Light to medium bodied, well-carbonated, slight slickness. Wow, joss, this ranks amongst the best from the already famous Ayingerbräu. Excellent beer, even bottled, wish I could taste this one from the Zwickelhahn one day.

light orange with quickly disapperaring large white head.  flavor is very subtle, the malt character is of  a very mild but pleasant caramel malt.  the bitterness is stronger than I expected and is a little distracting.  not as good as i had imagined, only a decent marzen

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2009 Gorgeous amber-orange pour with a nice fluffy head. Hoppy and nutty.
Everyone said I was going to LOVE it. They were wrong. SOMEONE owes me an Aventinus.

That was from last year...This year I hated it even more. If thats possible...It wasnt balanced...Too much hop, not enough malt. I guess if you have a steinfull at Oktoberfest in a beer drinking contest, it can be chugged and enjoyed...Im gonna go with Left Hand and Point this time.

A clear golden pour with plenty of visible carbonation.  Head is light orange.  Half of it dissipates quickly and noisily but the rest remains for a few minutes.  A fruity and spicy aroma that also offers pumpkin.  Flavor is subtle with nutmeg, toffee, honey, pumpkin, and light floral hop. It is on the sweet side.   Well carbonated up front but that fads mid glass.  Subtle flavors but plenty of them make for an enjoyable glass on a cool October day.

I give a bigger rating to this beer based on it’s style. For an Oktober, it’s unbelievable. For a great beer, it’s ok. There’s a nice malty aroma, as with most oktobers, with a nice crisp taste. Very suprising, for the style. This gave me a greater respect.

Delicious. I’m a huge Marzen fan, so I was looking forward to trying a highly rated, German-brewed one. Victory’s Festbier’s been my go to local beer, but Ayinger’s truly does belong to a higher class. The aroma is far more powerful, full of all of the sweet, toffee and caramel notes that I’d expect. It’s perfectly balanced, smooth and finishes crisp. If I was at Oktoberfest, I imagine I’d have about six too many of these. Superb.
keg and barrel tasting, wasn’t overly impressed, but did like the caramel and malt taste to this beer.  Nice color with desent head.  It’s wasn’t too thick not too thin, mouthfell was medium.

Clear amber pour with a thick frothy off-white head. Strong semi-sweet aroma of caramel and toffee, with just a touch of hops. Flavor follows the aroma nicely, but a bit more watery than expected. Palate is medium, feels big but very smooth. Very easy drinking, but one-dimensional, although thats somewhat expected from this style. Certainly one of the better Marzens

Bottle. This fest beer is pretty light weight. Good golden/amber color with a small thin head that didnt last. No lacing at all on glass. The aroma is delicate, as is the taste and mouth feel. Honestly, I expected more.

Clean, delicate malt aroma.  No diacetyl or hops in the mix.  Medium golden color, crystal clear, though minimal head and poor retention.  Flavor is similar to the aroma - delicate maltiness, some toasty notes, no hops or diacetyl.  Carbonation is a touch high, but not so much as to make it unenjoyable.  Overall, very tasty brew, well made and enjoyable.
a very good Marzen.  Enjoyed it very much.  Ayinger is an excellent brewery and this beer proves it.

Bottle  Perfect Pour.  Amber thick creamy white head.  Rich nose of toasted toffee bread rides undercurrents of sweet nutty grains.  Well balanced toasty caramel notes round to a light hop finish.  Medium bodied, light carbonation, dry malt finish.  One of the best out there.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Now that is a smooth mofo of a Oktoberfest.  Lots of sweet malts and a great mouthfeel.  Probably the best Marzen I’ve had so far in this life.
as it says mild aroma of floral hops with a sweet malty nose...great quafability ....all in all I could see how people could drink a ton of this beer at the good ole octoberfest
Coppery orange color, thin but lingering tan head. Tastes mildly like honey, very good. I liked this one a lot.
Awesome Oktoberfest beer.  A little sweet, a little hoppy, and plenty of grain dominates the palate.  White head on top of a golden body, great beer.

Courtesy of Tony @ OTH.
Pours golden, white head.
Aroma and taste has this ncie and sweet almost vegetable scent and mouthfeel. there is also plenty of nice malt and sweet sugar..
Another fine offering by Ayinger. They clearly have their own style.

A dark copper pour with a medium head.  The bear displays wonderful lacing. The taste is malty with some undertones of fruit (raisin?).  The texture seems quite thick, which lends to a strong palate feel.  This is a very enjoyable beer,

Very high quality brew here, it’s obvious even on the pour. Thick, copper hue with a huge beautiful looking head. Strong lacing as the brew is consumed. Taste is strongly bready, malty, biscuity -- quality oktoberfest here. Great texture, palate has just a bit of carbonation with a thick, full feel to it. Up there with the best marzens Ive had. Highly recommended.

Pours a deep golden color with a small lingering white head.  Aroma is malty and sweet with some pronounced plum and a light honey character. Flavor starts off with the sweet honey. A grainy bread character comes mid swallow followed by a bit of a bittersweet finish with more honey and some of the fruit character along with the bitter which goes away quickly. Medium body. Nice Oktoberfest but I don’t think I’d necessarily call it the best, since it feels a little too honey like.
nice, refreshing lager with citrus hints. Golden body with little to no head. Its not too much, but yet flavorful.
Amber with a nice two finger head. Aroma is caramely. Flavor is malty with a hint of hops. Nicely balanced beer. One of the best Octoberfests I’ve had.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008 This outstanding Marzen beer pours very clear golden color with a little bit of a coporish hue to it. Has a very fleeting off white head with very little to no lacing. The aroma is very malty... I cant detect any hops yet in the nose. Flavors of caramel lays lingering  on my taste buds. Barely a little spiciness  from the hops. After a swish in the glass as it warms a little there are hops in the nose, and alcohol. Its not too effervecent ( as light and fluffy) because of the full bodiness. The second pour in my glass gave me some flowery hops in my nostrels which quikly fades to big maltiness. Very smooth on the palate, with a soft dryness as described from brewer. Absolutely wonderful brew! Thank the Lord for the hop harvest.
on tap.  Great tasting beer for the month of October.   Wonderful, though I liked the Paulaner better.

1/2 liter bottle.  Pleasant aroma, fairly unimposing, a mild yet rich toffee, cookie, and a light lemon-citrus.  Pour had a pretty decent, 2 finger bubbly white head, dissipates almost entirely though, clear yet not watery looking, carbonation, blond-burnt orange in color.  A good tasting beer, a much smoother and creamier body than would be expected from the style, good variety of malt flavors with a nice toffee/caramel, along with a toasted cookie malt, balanced pretty well with a light citrus/floral hop that produces a very good linger with the malt.   Very nice overall, and perhaps undoubtedly the best of the style i have ever tried to this point.

Malty grainy aroma with touch of spicy hops. Mostly clear orange amber with small white head. Nice malt profile in flavor. Sweet with touch of almost orange citrus notes. Medium body and mouth feel. Finish is malty with touch of residual bitterness. Very Tasty
Great tasting beer perfect balance in the flavors very fitting for the season. not a bad price either

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2008 Poured a clear golden yellow with a good amount of carbonation bubbles throughout the glass. A tall creamy white head that slowly disappeared to just a film. There was some light lacing. A nice earthy sweet malt aroma. There was an initial crisp clean taste with good carbonation. A bit of sweetness at first followed by a good hop bite on the finish. A nice blend of sweet to hops. A nice full flavor and easy drinking

WITH-OUT ? 1 OF THE TOP MARZEN-OKTOBERFEST STYLES BAR-NONE.... the balance in the malt & hops is outstanding.. not over-cloying or sweet, just right amount, to make you want to keep pounding it down your worthless pie-hole

500ml bottle, poured a clear copper/amber, with a frothy off-white head.  Mild aroma of sweet toasted malt, caramel, and slight hops.  Taste of malt, caramel, and spices.  Mouthfeel is light and dry.  Pretty good!

500ml bottle:  Pours a pale amber color, just slightly darker than a macro lager.  Frothy off-white head.  Aroma consists of sweet malt, toffee and some spice.  Initial taste is of soft malts and toasted almond.  Just when you get the slightest hint of hops it finishes with a sweet, lingering caramel finsh.  Softly carbonated with a refreshing mouth feel.  Without a doubt the best Octoberfest I’ve had so far this season.

Over all I found this beer to be extremely plesant in all aspects and quite drinkable.  I will say I measure every oktoberfest up against Spaten, and perhaps I shouldn’t but I find Spaten to simply be amazing.  Personally I didn’t find it to be something I would want over a Spaten, except on occasion when  I needed a break.

If you get some you wont be disappointed and might even find yourself enjoying it.

Pours a golden color with a good sided white head.  Leaves some soapy lacing.  Sweat malty aroma.  Love the mouth feel on this one.  Flavors of caramel, spice and a light hop kick on the end.  Good carbonation.  Excellent beer.

on tap-pours a thin white head and gold color.  Aroma is light/medium malt-honey, faint spice hops.  Taste is light/medium malt-honey, secondary earthy/spice-hops, some bite/copper.  Hops is the after taste.
Pours a light amber with a nice white head.  Aroma is nice and malty.  Big delicious caramel malt taste, a great marzen.
500ml bottle. Clear coppery pour with a nice off white head. Bready and malty, light caramel, somewhat sweet. A nip of grassy hop. Not bad!

(Bottle).  Semi-sweet bready malt aroma.  Golden color with medium head.  Flavor is malty and pleasantly semi-sweet, with hops also evident.   Mild but lasting finish.  Nice quality brew, but perhaps just a bit over-rated.

My catagoration of this beer would be to mix a wheat beer with an octoberfest.  This is one of the lighter color octoberfest beers and it has a flavor very consistent with a wheat beer.  This is an exception beer.

Bomber from the bottle shelf for $1.49 Poured a nice copper color with a thick head. Aroma of sweet malts and a slight citrus note. Flavor was rather "crisp" and "spicy?" witha back bone of sweet malts. A rather dry mouthfeel, I dont know why but this Octoberfest didnt move me the way Hacker-Pschorr did.

Darnit, just missed being rater no 555!  Bottle, should be fresh.  Lovely nose, rich pale malt with caramel overtones and lots of lovely spice.  Touch of grass and light, perky citrus.  Clear golden with a rocky off-white head.  Taste is tart and lightly acidic, spicy lightish bread with clear German hops and a soothing, soft body.  Soft water.  Touch of toast edging toward smoke.  Light-medium body, but a rich malt base.  Super, one of the best, and thankfully, relatively easy to find.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2009 Bottle. Pours clear dark gold with a big, fluffy off-white head. Nose is grassy hops and a bit of nice, clean, sweet bready malt. Taste is crisp and clean, bready malt with a bit of caramel, hint of brown sugar, perfect amount of grassy hops on the finish to balance. Medium bodied and medium carbonation. Really nice - nothing in the least bit extreme, but still supremely satisfying on one of the first cool evenings of fall.

500ml bottle.  Pours a bright pumpkin orange with a nice thick foamy white cap that leaves sudsy lacing.  Aroma is very sweet, malty, some plastic, and a little bit of alcohol.  I cant describe exactly why but I dont really like the aroma.  The plastic or the alcohol is distracting.  It smells a little like a light Barleywine.   Flavor is smooth and does not have any of the negative effects of the aroma.  Crisp, somewhat dry.  A pretty quick finish with just a touch of residual sweetness.  This is fine but does not stick out as a great Octoberfest to me

The aroma is caramel malts, with an earthy, hay/grass character.  The color is true to the style, an ornage/gold, although slightly closer to gold.  Malty/fruity flavor, medium mouthfeel.  The finish is malty, with a slight amount of hops.  Good Marzen overall, still not the best.

2008 Bottle - Pours lt brown with a huge white head..aroma is caramel malt and hay, flavour follows with a nice balance...this is more dry than the others so far, the sweetness is in the nose, and the flavour is rather light by comparison...very nice....
Medium yellow amber color with large head.  Decent mix of hops and malts.  Good mouth feel.
keg 330ml 4e at OpusK Lohja 160908 color:orange creamy head strong carbonation. Taste: strong malty and fruity delicious one. Have to re-rate later on maybe without massive carbonation

bottle.  glowing copper pour with thick foamy head.  sweet malty aroma.  smooth and subtle.  medium body.  well balanced.  light sweetness that last through finish.  dry at the end.  light fruit and earthy hops.  great marzen.
Clear amber with a sweet malty smell.  Nice balance of hops and malt make this example refreshing and smooth.  All too often Marzens are overly sweet.  This one is right on the mark.

Bottle.  Pours a clear light orange with a thick white head.  Aroma of stale wheat, some sweet malt.  Flavor of lots of that stale wheat yeast, which I’m not really a fan of, and some light fruits (apple, pear).  Too bland.  Not really my style but in my opinion, this isn’t one of the better examples of it.
